THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Sandra Bartley,
          Claimant, Appellant,
        v.
        Allendale County School District, Employer, and S.C. School Boards
          Insurance Trust, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Allendale County
  Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4476
  Heard October 22, 2008 â€“ Filed January 8,
2009

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jonathan R. Hendrix, of Lexington, for
          Appellant.
        Kirsten L. Barr, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KONDUROS,
  J.:Â In this workerâ€™s compensation action, Sandra Bartley[1] appeals the Appellate Panelâ€™s failure to find her
  totally and permanently disabled, arguing it failed to consider the combined
  effects of a workplace injury and a pre-existing problem.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On
  September 26, 2002, Bartley was employed as a teacher at Fairfax Elementary School for the Allendale County School District (the District).Â  During recess, a
  fifth-grade student with cerebral palsy ran towards Bartley to give her a hug.Â 
  The student inadvertently knocked Bartley down onto some tree roots and fell on
  top of her.Â  Bartley did not go to an emergency room for treatment but had
  cervical fusion surgery on May 14, 2003.Â  On July 18, 2003, Bartley filed a
  Form 50, alleging injuries from the incident (the Allendale incident) to the
  right shoulder, neck, right arm and hand, left knee, and migraine headaches.
On
  July 24, 2003, her treating physician, Dr. Scott Strohmeyer, noted that Bartley
  was doing great, her neck was great, and she was in no pain.Â  Because Bartleyâ€™s
  husband had lost his job in Allendale, they moved to Columbia to live with his
  parents.Â  Bartley was feeling better and in August 2003 she began
  teaching special education in Richland County at Richland One.Â  She completed a
  medical questionnaire indicating she did not have a problem with arthritis,
  back pain, joint pain, or any other chronic illness.Â  While working at Richland
  One, she began having new symptoms after lifting heavy books and working long
  hours.Â  In October 2003, at Richland One, a student lifted a desk and threatened
  to throw it at her.Â  The incident (the Richland incident) made Bartley
  feel fearful again and brought back the memories of being physically hurt.Â  On
  July 8, 2004, Dr. Strohmeyer noted â€œshe did very well from [the cervical fusion]
  and then she went back to teaching school and had another incident with a
  student and, since that time, she has had a lot of neck pain, right-sided arm
  pain, lower back pain and pain down her leg.â€ Â In September 2004,
  Bartley had fusion surgery in her lower back as a result of a large facet cyst.Â 
  On December 10, 2004, Bartley filed another Form 50, alleging injuries to the
  buttocks, right leg, dizziness, ringing in the ears, and psychological overlay.
On August 8, 2005,
  the single commissioner conducted a hearing.Â  At the hearing, Bartley testified
  that about a week after the accident, she noticed she could not raise her right
  arm to write on the blackboard.Â  As time progressed, she could not get
  out of bed without assistance.Â  She further testified she had children
  at school carry her books for her, had trouble walking, and stopped exercising.
However,
  Bartley testified that following the cervical fusion, she started doing better;
  her headaches and ringing in her ear were better and she regained the range of
  motion in her right arm.Â  She also testified she â€œhad initially done
  well [after the surgery] but after doing a lot of the lifting and everything
  the pain had began . . . .â€ Â Further, Bartley indicated she did not feel
  fearful after her cervical fusion but the Richland incident â€œmade [her] feel
  fearful again.â€Â  Additionally, she discussed her lower back fusion but
  explained â€œI donâ€™t think my low back problem is related to [the Allendale
  incident].â€
At
  the time of the hearing, Bartley asserted she was having problems with her neck
  hurting, back pain, lack of strength in her right arm, loss of balance, and
  dizziness.Â  She also testified she was having problems with her memory;
  she would pay bills more than once, get lost while driving, or forget to take
  her medicine.
The
  District presented evidence, including Bartleyâ€™s own testimony, she had
  problems with depression dating back to 1987.Â  In March of 2001, she
  visited a doctor because she had nausea and dizziness and blacked out.Â  At
  the visit, she said she had three other episodes when she was nauseated and
  almost blacked out.Â  Additionally, in January of 2002, she informed her
  doctor her migraines had gotten worse.Â  In February 2002, it was noted
  on her patient chart she â€œsuffers from fibromyalgia and also depression and
  migraine headaches.Â  She comes in with multiple complaints. . . . She has an
  increase in her migraines.Â  She states that she used to get a couple a year and
  over the last four to five weeks she has had several.â€Â  She also
  complained of ringing in her ears at that doctorâ€™s visit, which the doctor
  believed was likely Eustachian tube dysfunction. Â The chart also
  contained a notation that Bartley appeared to be more depressed.Â  Dr.
  Mark Lencke believed a congenital Chiari-1 malformation at the base of her
  skull might be causing her neck pain and depression as well as chronic
  headaches.Â  Bartley also testified at the hearing she previously was in
  abusive marriage and had been abused as a child.Â  Additionally, she
  testified she had been taking Adderall beginning in 1999 after telling her
  doctor she had â€œalways been disorganized and unfocused.â€
The
  District also presented a letter from Dr. Strohmeyer, dated January 27, 2005,
  in which he responded to the question: â€œ[I]is the condition of lumbar stenosis
  related to the accident that happened in October 2003 at the patientâ€™s
  employment[?]â€Â  He answered, â€œThat is difficult to assess.Â  She had a facet
  disk that has caused severe stenosis.Â  These can be trauma related or just from
  degenerative changes.Â  It is very difficult to rule out trauma as being a contributing
  problem to that condition.â€
Bartley
  presented opinions of doctors and a physical therapist that she suffers from
  post-traumatic stress.Â  Additionally, at his deposition, Dr. Strohmeyer
  explained Bartley was still having problems related to the Allendale incident
  or the cervical fusion.Â  Dr. Strohmeyer stated he did not think she
  could handle the physical demands of being a special needs school teacher.Â  He
  also agreed Bartley was probably disabled from working full time and thought
  that was due to the Allendale incident.
The
  single commissioner found Bartley suffered an injury to her neck arising in and
  out of the course of employment on September 26, 2002.Â  Accordingly, the
  commissioner determined Bartley had suffered a thirty percent permanent loss of
  use of her back.Â  The commissioner gave the physical therapistâ€™s opinion that
  Bartley suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder no weight because she was
  not a medical doctor or psychiatrist.Â  The commissioner further noted Dr.
  Drummond discussed post-traumatic stress disorder but did not link it to the
  Allendale incident. Â The commissioner further found Bartley was not
  disabled as a result of the injury because she began work with Richland One in
  August 2003, and thus, was not entitled to temporary total disability.Â 
  Additionally, the commissioner determined she â€œfailed to carry the burden of
  proof by competent medical evidence that she suffered an injury to any body
  part other than her neck or that her psychological condition has worsened as a
  result of this injury.â€Â  The commissioner also found Bartley did not file
  claims for benefits for the buttocks, low back, right leg, dizziness, ringing
  in the ears, or psychological disorder within two years of the date of injury,
  and thus, those claims were barred by the statute of limitations.
Bartley appealed to the Appellate Panel arguing the
  commissioner erred in ruling a substantial portion of her claims were barred by
  the statute of limitations.Â  Bartley also asserted the commissioner
  erred in failing to find her permanently and totally disabled or that she had
  sustained a much greater degree of disability in failing to award
  temporary-total benefits. Â She further contended the commissioner erred in failing
  to award her additional medical benefits including past and future medical
  expenses.Â  Following a hearing, the Appellate Panel affirmed the single
  commissioner finding Bartley had suffered a thirty percent permanent loss of
  her back from the incident but determined the claims for the buttocks, low
  back, right leg, dizziness, ringing in the ears, and psychological disorders
  were not barred by the statute of limitations.Â  However, the Appellate
  Panel determined those problems were not caused by the Allendale incident.
Bartley appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed
  the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.Â  The circuit court found the Appellate
  Panel properly considered Bartleyâ€™s pre-existing conditions and determined they
  were not caused or aggravated by the Allendale incident.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative
  Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions
  by the Appellate Panel.Â  See Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130,
  134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court may not substitute
  its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence
  on questions of fact, but may reverse when the decision is affected by an error
  of law.Â  Stone v. Traylor Bros., 360 S.C. 271, 274, 600 S.E.2d 551, 552
(Ct. App. 2004).
The
  substantial evidence rule governs the standard of review in workersâ€™
  compensation decisions.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593
  S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s
  decision must be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  An appellate court can reverse or modify the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the decision is affected by an error of law
  or is â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial
  evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 619, 611 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2005).

  â€œSubstantial
    evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly
    from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a
    whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the
    administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its
    action.

Lark,
276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306.
â€œ[T]he possibility of drawing two
  inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative
  agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Palmetto
    Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d
  695, 696 (1984).Â  In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Appellate Panel is the
  ultimate finder of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535
  S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000Â  When the evidence is
  conflicting over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate Panel are
  conclusive.Â  Hargrove v. Titan
    Textile Co.,360 S.C. 276,
  290, 599 S.E.2d 604, 611 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The
  final determination of witness credibility and weight of the
  evidence is reserved for the Appellate Panel.Â  Bass
    v. Kenco Group,366 S.C. 450,
458, 622 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bartley
  argues the single commissioner, Appellate Panel, and circuit court all erred in
  failing to consider the combined effects of a workplace injury and preexisting
  physical and/or emotional and mental problems.Â  Specifically, Bartley maintains
  the Appellate Panel erred in relying on this courtâ€™s decision in Ellison v.
    Frigidaire Home Products, 360 S.C. 236, 600 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 2004) (Ellison
      I), which the supreme court reversed, 371 S.C. 159, 638 S.E.2d 664 (2006) (Ellison
        II).Â  Further, Bartley contends because substantial, reliable, competent,
  and probative evidence in the record as a whole supports that she is totally
  disabled and her psychological and physical problems affect more than just her
  back and hinder her employment, she must be awarded additional benefits.Â  We
disagree.
For an injury to be compensable, it must arise out of
  and in the course of employment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160(A) (Supp. 2007). Â An
  injury arises out of employment if a causal relationship between the conditions
  under which the work is to be performed and the resulting injury is apparent to
  the rational mind, upon consideration of all the
  circumstances.Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 518, 466
  S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996).Â  â€œThe claimant has the burden of proving facts that will
  bring the injury within the workersâ€™ compensation law, and such award must not
  be based on surmise, conjecture or speculation.â€Â  Clade v. Champion Labs., 330 S.C. 8, 11, 496
  S.E.2d 856, 857 (1998).
Under section 42-9-10 of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2007), a claimant has three ways to obtain total disability.Â  First, a
  claimant can be presumptively disabled.Â Â  

  The list of injuries included in the presumptive total
    disability category include: â€œ[t]he loss of both hands, arms, feet, legs, or
    vision in both eyes, or any two thereof, constitutes total and permanent
    disability to be compensated according to the provisions of this sectionâ€ or
    that claimant â€œis a paraplegic, a quadriplegic, or who has suffered physical
    brain damage. . . .â€

Wigfall
  v. Tideland Utils., Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 105 n.4, 580 S.E.2d 100, 102 n.4 (2003)
  (quoting Â§ 42-9-10) (alteration and omission by court).Â  For these
  injuries, a claimant need not show a loss of earning capacity because the loss
  is conclusively presumed.Â  Id. at 105, 580 S.E.2d at 102.Â  Second, a
  claimant can show an injury that is not a scheduled injury under section
  42-9-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) â€œcaused sufficient loss of
  earning capacity to render him totally disabled.â€Â  Wigfall, 354
  S.C. at 105, 580 S.E.2d at 102.Â  â€œThird, a claimant may establish total
  disability through multiple physical injuries.â€Â  Id. at 106, 580 S.E.2d
  at 103.
When a mental injury is induced by physical injury, unlike
  a purely mental injury, it is not necessary that it result from unusual or
  extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 464-65,
  622 S.E.2d 577, 584 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Additionally, â€œ[a]ggravation of pre-existing
  psychiatric problems is compensable if that aggravation is caused by a
  work-related physical injury.â€ Â Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 493, 541
  S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â  Pre-existing
  depression does not preclude workersâ€™ compensation benefits for a mental
  injury. Â See Doe v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities & Special Needs, 377
  S.C. 346, 351, 660 S.E.2d 260, 263 (2008).Â  However, the right of
  a claimant to compensation for aggravation of a pre-existing condition arises
  only when the claimant has a dormant condition that has produced no disability
  but becomes disabling because of the aggravating injury. Â Anderson, 343
  S.C. at 493, 541 S.E.2d at 528.

  The
    language of [section] 42-9-400(a) and (d) indicates the legislature clearly
    envisioned that a claimant may recover for greater disability than that
    incurred from a single injury to a particular body part if the combination with
    any pre-existing condition hinders reemployment. Â There is no requirement that
    the pre-existing condition aggravated the injury, or that the injury aggravated
    the pre-existing condition, so long as there is a greater disability simply
    from the â€œcombined effectsâ€ of the injury and the pre-existing condition.FN4
  FN4. In fact, the statute provides for the aggravation
    of a pre-existing condition as an alternative to the combined effects
    provision.


    Ellison II, 371 S.C. at 164, 638 S.E.2d at 666. Â â€œ[A]n injured claimant is entitled to compensation and
  medical benefits for disability arising from a permanent physical impairment in
  combination with a pre-existing impairment if the combined effect results in a
  substantially greater disability.â€ Â Curiel v. Envtl. Mgmt. Servs. (MS),
  376 S.C. 23, 31, 655 S.E.2d 482, 486 (2007) (citing Ellison v.
    Frigidaire Home Prods., 371 S.C. 159, 638 S.E.2d 664 (2006)).
South
  Carolina has adopted the â€œlast injurious exposure rule,â€ which 

  places
    full liability upon the carrier covering
    the risk at the time of the most recent injury that bears a causal relation to
    the disability. Â Consistent with the rule that an employer takes its employee
    as it finds her, the last injurious exposure rule makes the insurer at risk at
    the time of the second injury liable even if the second injury would have been
    much less severe in the absence of the prior condition and even if the prior
    injury significantly contributed to the final condition. Â However, if the
    second injury is merely a recurrence of the first injury, then the insurer on
    the risk at the time of the original injury remains liable for the second.

Geathers v. 3V, Inc., 371 S.C. 570, 577-78, 641 S.E.2d 29, 33 (2007)
  (quotations and citations omitted).
In Gordon v. E. I. Du Pont De Nemours and Co., 228 S.C. 67, 76, 88 S.E.2d 844, 848 (1955) (citations omitted), the
  South Carolina Supreme Court held when

  a latent or quiescent weakened, but not disabling,
    condition resulting from disease is by accidental injury in the course and
    scope of employment aggravated or accelerated or activated, with resulting
    disability, such disability is compensable. Â The same principle is equally
    applicable whe[n] the latent, but not disabling, condition has resulted from a
    prior accidental injury. Â If the disability is proximately caused by the
    subsequent accidental injury,
    compensability is referable to that, and not the earlier one.

In Geathers, 371 S.C. at 580, 641 S.E.2d at 34, the supreme court applied Gordon because â€œ(1) Claimant suffered a non-disabling back injury during
  a workplace accident; (2) Claimantâ€™s disability was caused by the second accident;
  and (3) the second injury â€˜aggravated or accelerated or activatedâ€™ the
  pre-existing condition.â€Â  The court further held the Gordon rule â€œreflects the essence of the last
  injurious exposure rule[,] which is to hold the insurer on the risk at the time
  of the second injury solely liable when the second injury aggravates the first
  injury.â€Â  Id.
Expert medical testimony is designed to aid the
  Appellate Panel in coming to the correct conclusion; therefore, the Appellate
  Panel determines the weight and credit to be given to the expert testimony.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999).Â  Â Â â€œOnce admitted, expert testimony is to be considered just
  like any other testimony.â€ Â Id.Â  Accordingly, in deciding whether
  substantial evidence supports a finding of causation, we consider both the lay
  and expert evidence.Â  Id. at 341, 513 S.E.2d at 847. Â While medical
  testimony is entitled to great respect, it should not be held conclusive
  irrespective of other evidence and the fact finder may disregard it if the record
  includes other competent evidence.Â  Id. at 340, 513
  S.E.2d at 846.Â  
 The record contains
  substantial evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding Bartleyâ€™s
  injuries for the buttocks, low back, right leg, dizziness, ringing in the ears,
  and psychological disorder were not caused by the Allendale incident.Â  Bartley
  was doing well and returned to work after the surgery for her injury from the
  Allendale accident.Â  Dr. Strohmeyer indicated the symptoms for which she is
  seeking to recover were likely related to the Richland incident or her unrelated
  lower back problem.Â  Even Bartley testified she was no longer experiencing
  problems until she lifted some books at Richland One.Â  Additionally, Bartley
  underwent lumbar fusion surgery, ankle surgery, and a hysterectomy that were
  all unrelated to the Allendale incident.Â  Further, Bartley has a long history
  of suffering from depression and migraine headaches.
Although
  Bartley presented some evidence the Allendale incident aggravated Bartleyâ€™s
  pre-existing conditions, the record also contains substantial evidence the
  Allendale incident did not cause or aggravate her conditions.Â  Substantial
  evidence may support finding either the Richland incident aggravated her
  pre-existing conditions or that her pre-existing conditions were not aggravated
  at all because she was experiencing the same problems before the accident.Â 
  Accordingly, Ellison II does not apply.Â  The Appellate Panel is the
  ultimate fact finder and when the facts conflict, as they do here, its findings
  are conclusive.Â  The record contains substantial evidence supporting the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.Â  Therefore, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON
and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.


[1] Bartleyâ€™s son
  accompanied her to oral arguments. Â Judge Williams believed he recognized the
  young man, who identified himself as a member of the South Carolina Judicial
  Departmentâ€™s information technology unit. Neither counsel for the case sub
    judice objected to this panel hearing the matter.

title: Ex Parte: Mamie L. Jackson
description: Mamie Jackson appeals the trial court's decision to hold her in contempt and her ninety-day imprisonment sentence.  We reverse.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ex Parte: Mamie
          L. Jackson, Appellant,
        In Re: City of Columbia, Respondent,
        v.
        Mamie L.
          Jackson, Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4477
  Submitted November 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January
8, 2009

REVERSED 


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Elizabeth A. Franklin, South Carolina
          Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Peter M. Balthazor, Office of the City Attorney, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Mamie
  Jackson (Jackson) appeals the trial courtâ€™s decision to hold her in contempt
  and her imprisonment sentence of ninety days.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
The City of Columbia (the City) commenced an action against Jackson seeking injunctive relief.Â  Among the grounds for relief, the City sought to enjoin
  Jackson from accumulating rubbish and debris on her property as prohibited by
  the Cityâ€™s Code.Â  The trial court granted the Cityâ€™s request and enjoined Jackson from accumulating junk, clutter, and debris on her property.Â  Additionally, the
  trial court granted the Cityâ€™s request to abate the conditions that constituted
  a violation of the Cityâ€™s Property Maintenance Code.Â  Subsequently, the City removed
  and disposed of the junk, clutter, and debris on Jacksonâ€™s property.Â  
Approximately two months after this hearing, the City brought a
  petition for rule to show cause as to why Jackson should not be held in
  contempt for violating the trial courtâ€™s order prohibiting her from
  accumulating junk, clutter, and debris on her property.Â  The City argued that
  less than a week after it removed the items on Jacksonâ€™s property, Jackson brought additional clutter, debris, and junk back onto her property.Â  
The trial court held a hearing to determine if Jackson was in
  contempt.Â  Jackson appeared pro se and argued she did not violate the trial
  courtâ€™s order because she did not bring additional items onto the property but
  rather moved the items from inside the house to outside the house for storage
  purposes.Â  The trial court rejected this argument and found Jackson in contempt
  and sentenced her to ninety days imprisonment.Â  This appeal follows.[1]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Courts have inherent power to punish for contemptuous conduct.Â  Miller
  v. Miller, 375 S.C. 443, 453-54, 652 S.E.2d 754, 759-60 (Ct. App. 2007) (internal
  citations omitted).Â Â Â  Courts are vested by their very creation with the power
  to preserve order in judicial proceedings and to enforce judgments and orders.Â  Id.Â  Contempt results from the willful disobedience of a courtâ€™s
  order.Â  Id.Â  A willful act is defined as one which is done voluntarily
  and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or
  with specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done.Â  Id.Â  
Initially, we must determine whether the contempt involved in this
  case was civil or criminal.Â  The determination of whether contempt is civil or
  criminal hinges on the underlying purpose of the contempt ruling.Â  Id. at 456-57, 652 S.E.2d at 761.Â  If the primary purpose of contempt is to coerce a
  party to do the thing required by the court for the benefit of the complainant,
  then the contempt is considered civil.Â  Id.Â  However, if the principal
  function of the contempt is to preserve the courtâ€™s authority and to punish a
  party for disobedience of the courtâ€™s order, then it is criminal.Â  Id.Â  Punishment for civil contempt is remedial in that sanctions are conditioned on
  compliance with the courtâ€™s order, whereas an unconditional penalty is
  considered criminal contempt because it is solely and exclusively punitive in
  nature.Â  Id.
In the present case, the contempt imposed was criminal because the
  function of the sanctions imposed was to punish Jackson for disobedience of the
  trial courtâ€™s order.Â  Namely, the trial court sought to punish Jackson because she violated the order prohibiting her from accumulating junk, clutter, and
  debris on her property.Â  Furthermore, the punishment imposed, the ninety days
  imprisonment, was unconditional in that Jackson did not have an opportunity to
  purge herself of the sanctions if she complied with the court order.Â  Thus, the
  trial court viewed the sanctions as criminal rather than civil.Â  See id. (holding a sentence of imprisonment is considered punitive, and therefore
  criminal contempt, if it is limited to a definite period). 
The distinction between civil and criminal
  contempt is crucial because criminal contempt triggers additional
  constitutional safeguards.Â  Id.Â  The
  Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution ensure that
  an individual be afforded the right to assistance of counsel before he or she
  can be validly convicted and punished by imprisonment.Â  State v. Thompson,
  355 S.C. 255, 261-62, 584 S.E.2d 131, 134-35 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The right to counsel is by far the most pervasive, for it
  affects a personâ€™s ability to assert any other rights he or she may have.Â  Id. The erroneous deprivation of this right constitutes per se reversible error.Â  Id.Â  
 It is,
  however, possible to waive the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  Id.Â  To effectuate a valid waiver of the right to counsel, the accused must (1) be advised
  of the right to counsel and (2) be adequately warned of the dangers of self-representation.Â  State v. McLauren, 349 S.C. 488, 493-94, 563 S.E.2d 346, 348-49 (Ct.
  App. 2002) (â€œFaretta[2] requires that a defendant be made aware of the dangers and disadvantages of
  self-representation so that the record will establish he knows what he is doing
  and his choice is made with eyes open.â€) (internal citations and quotations
  omitted).Â  It is the trial courtâ€™s responsibility to determine whether there
  was a knowing and intelligent wavier by the accused.Â  Thompson,
  355 S.C. at 261-62, 584 S.E.2d at 134-35. A specific
  inquiry by the trial court expressly addressing the disadvantages of appearing
  pro se is preferred.Â  Id. at 262-63, 584 S.E.2d at 134-35. 
If the trial court
  fails to address the disadvantages of appearing pro se, this Court will examine
  the record to determine whether the accused had sufficient background or was
  apprised of his rights by some other source.Â  McLauren, 349 S.C. at 494,
  563 S.E.2d at 349. Consequently, when determining whether the accused knowingly
  and voluntarily waived his or her right to counsel the â€œultimate test is not
  the trial judgeâ€™s advice but rather the defendantâ€™s understanding.â€Â  Thompson,
  355 S.C. at 262-63, 584 S.E.2d at 135.
The following factors are to be considered in determining if the
  accused had a sufficient background to understand the disadvantages of
  self-representation:

  (1) the accusedâ€™s age, educational
    background, and physical and mental health;
  (2) whether the accused was previously
    involved in criminal trials;
  (3) whether he knew of the nature of the
    charge and of the possible penalties;
  (4) whether he was represented by counsel
    before trial or whether an attorney indicated to him the difficulty of
    self-representation in his particular case;
  (5) whether he was attempting to delay or
    manipulate the proceedings;
  (6) whether the court appointed stand-by
    counsel;
  (7) whether the accused knew he would be
    required to comply with the rules of procedure at trial;
  (8) whether he knew of legal challenges he
    could raise in defense to the charges against him;
  (9) whether the exchange between the
    accused and the court consisted merely of pro forma answers to pro
      forma questions; and
  (10) whether the accusedâ€™s waiver resulted
    from either coercion or mistreatment.

McLauren, 349 S.C. at 494, 563 S.E.2d at 349.
In the present case, the trial court conducted a hearing to determine if Jackson was in contempt.Â 
  Jackson appeared pro se at this hearing.Â  At the conclusion of the hearing, the trial court sentenced Jackson to ninety days imprisonment. The
  record is completely devoid of any statements by the trial court informing Jackson of her right to counsel.Â  Additionally, the record does not reveal the trial court
  warned Jackson in any way as to the dangers of self-representation.Â  Moreover,
  the trial court did not
  determine, as required, that Jackson knowingly and intelligently waived the
  right to counsel.Â  
Our examination of the record does not reveal Jackson had a sufficient
  background or was apprised of her constitutional right to counsel by another
  source.Â  Consequently, the trial courtâ€™s decision to sentence Jackson to ninety days imprisonment was reversible
  error.Â  Thompson, 355 S.C. at 262-63, 584 S.E.2d at 134-35. (holding the erroneous deprivation of the right to counsel
  constitutes per se reversible error).[3]
We
  note that this opinion is limited to the issue of constructive contempt.Â 
  Constructive contempt is contemptuous conduct occurring outside the presence of
  the court, whereas direct contempt is defined as contemptuous conduct that
  occurs in the presence of the court.Â  Miller, 375 S.C. at 455, 652
  S.E.2d at 760.Â  In the present case, the contemptuous conduct was Jacksonâ€™s failure to comply with the
  court order prohibiting her from accumulating junk, clutter, and debris on her
  property.Â  This conduct occurred outside the presence of the court and is
  therefore constructive contempt.[4]
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED.[5]
PIEPER,
and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1] Jackson was released from custody pending the appeal and appointed
  counsel.
[2] Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975).
[3] The City argues the issue of whether Jackson was entitled to counsel is not preserved for review because the trial court did not
  address it.Â  We disagree.Â  â€œA notable exception to this general rule requiring
  a contemporaneous objection is found when the record does not reveal a knowing
  and intelligent wavier of the right to counsel.Â  The pro se defendant cannot be
  expected to raise this issue without the aid of counsel.â€Â  State v.
    Rocheville, 310 S.C. 20, 25, 425 S.E.2d 32, 35 (1993).Â  Thus, Jackson was not required to preserve this issue for our review. 
[4] Jackson raises other issues on appeal.Â  Due to the disposition
  of the right to counsel issue, we need not address these issues.Â  Futch v.
    McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591,
  598 (1999) (â€œAn
  appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior
  issue is dispositive.â€).Â  
[5] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Turner v. Milliman
description: In this fraud and negligent misrepresentation action, the Turners appeal from the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of an insurance agent and several insurance companies. The Court of Appeals held the trial court erred in finding the statute of limitations had expired, but affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment because the insurance agent's representations were not actionable as a matter of law.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John and
      Charlene Turner, Appellants,
				v.
				Douglas A.
      Milliman, Consumer Benefits of America, NIA Corporation, Mid America Life
      Insurance Co., World Service Life Insurance Co., Provident American Life and
      Health Insurance Co., Provident Indemnity Life Insurance Co., and Central
      Reserve Life Insurance Co., Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4478
Heard December 3, 2008 â€“ Filed January 12,
  2009
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				
					John W. Carrigg, Jr., of Columbia, for
  Appellants.
					Jonathan Matthew Harvey, of Columbia, Lawrence B. Orr, 
					of Florence, Stephanie G. Flynn and Phillip E. Reeves, of Greenville, for Respondents.
				
			
		
	

GEATHERS, J.: In
  this fraud and negligent misrepresentation action, Appellants John and Charlene Turner (collectively â€œthe
  Turnersâ€) appeal from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of
  Respondents Douglas Milliman (â€œMillimanâ€), Consumer Benefits of America
  (â€œCBAâ€), National Insurance Alliance Corporation, MidAmerica Life Insurance
  Company (â€œMidAmericaâ€), World
  Service Life Insurance Company, Provident American Life and Health Insurance
  Company (â€œProvident Americanâ€), Provident Indemnity Life Insurance Company
  (â€œProvident Indemnityâ€), and Central Reserve Life Insurance Company
  (collectively â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  On appeal,
  the Turners argue the trial court erred in finding that their claims were
  barred by the three-year statute of limitations; in finding that Millimanâ€™s
  representations to the Turners were insufficient to support a claim for fraud or
  negligent misrepresentation; in holding that Millimanâ€™s statements to John
  Turner (â€œTurnerâ€) were not attributable to MidAmerica or CBA because Milliman
  was an insurance broker and not an insurance agent; and, in holding that
  Turnerâ€™s wife did not have standing to sue Respondents.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
In November 1996, Turner was in need of health
  insurance coverage.Â  One of Turnerâ€™s customers recommended Milliman, a local insurance
  agent,[1] Â whom Turner subsequently contacted. Turnerâ€™s health insurance had recently
  expired after he left his prior employment at an accounting firm.Â  At the time
  that Turner sought Millimanâ€™s services, Turner was employed at the familyâ€™s radiator
  service business.Â  Â 
The
  Turners and Milliman discussed Turnerâ€™s health insurance options, specifically
  the option to purchase group health insurance.Â  Milliman represented to Turner
  that a group policy with CBA would be a good option because the future premiums
  would not increase dramatically or as dramatically as the premiums with
  individual insurance plans.Â  Turner also alleged that Milliman stated group
  health insurance would be beneficial because of the following: (1) Turner was
  at an age when he could start developing medical problems and this policy would
  allow him to keep his coverage; (2) companies writing individual insurance
  policies were going out of business and the prices of those policies were skyrocketing;
  and (3) the only way people could afford insurance was to purchase group
  insurance.Â  Turner further stated that Milliman told him CBA acted as a
  watchdog over the insurance industry for the benefit of its members and would
  notify its members when better group coverage was available.Â  
Based on these alleged representations, Turner
  completed an application for group health insurance through CBA.Â  This group
  insurance coverage was issued by MidAmerica, which was concurrently assumed and
  reinsured by Provident Indemnity.[2] Â Turnerâ€™s first premium payment in November 1996 was $122.70, which represented
  his monthly health insurance premium as well as CBA membership dues.[3]Â 
  From the following month until May 1997, $101.70 was drafted from Turnerâ€™s account
  for his monthly health insurance premium.Â  In June 1997, Turnerâ€™s premium
  increased to $109.70 and did not increase for eleven months.Â  In June 1998, his
  premium increased to $143.38, and in December 1998, his premium again increased
  to $194.50. Â During the following two years, his premiums increased every six
  months (June 1999, $230.90; December 1999, $271.95; June 2000, $331.81; and December
  2000, $456.21). Â Turner stated he always anticipated the premiums would
  increase, but by the end of 1999 into 2000, he thought the increases were becoming
  unreasonable and â€œjust getting completely out of hand.â€ 
On
  April 30, 2001, CBA informed Turner that his monthly premium would increase to
  $646.19 on June 1, 2001 due to increased research and development healthcare
  costs.Â  Then, on May 31, 2001, CBA again notified Turner that his
  premium would increase to $799.61 on July 1, 2001, because of â€œrising
  healthcare costs as well as the substantial and continued losses sustained by
  Provident American. . . .â€Â  Â Â 
In June 2001, as a result of the continued increases
  in Turnerâ€™s premiums, Turner submitted a complaint to the South Carolina Department
  of Insurance.Â  The Department of Insurance wrote Provident American inquiring
  about its premium rate increases.Â  In response to the Department of Insuranceâ€™s
  letter, Provident American told the Department that Turnerâ€™s insurance contract
  permitted the company to increase rates with thirty-one days advance written
  notice and that â€œit had no alternative but to increase premium rates.â€Â 
  Provident American also represented to the Department of Insurance that â€œ[its]
  members were accustomed to receiving biannual premium rate adjustments,â€ and
  the May 31, 2001 increase â€œaffect[ed] all current . . . certificate holders.â€Â 
  Thereafter, the Department of Insurance notified Turner that he was insured
  under a â€œgroup association policy,â€ and as such, those rates were not subject
  to approval by the Department.Â  Â 
On
  June 22, 2001, Provident American notified Turner that it would unilaterally terminate
  the CBA group association policy, but Turner could reinsure under another group
  policy for the same initial premium with substantially fewer benefits.Â  Turner
  testified that he attempted to find alternate health care coverage, but due to
  the onset of diabetes, no insurance company would insure him.Â  Turner paid his
  premiums until Provident American terminated his policy in September 2001, and he
  has been without health insurance since this time.Â  Â Â 
On December 19,
  2003, the Turners initiated suit against Respondents for fraud, negligent
  misrepresentation, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices
  Act (â€œSCUTPAâ€).[4]Â 
  In essence, the Turners alleged that Milliman, as an agent of Respondents, made
  several false representations that induced Turner to sign the insurance application
  and purchase the group policy from CBA.Â  The Turners stated that because
  of the excessive premium increases, they were unable to maintain the policy,
  which ultimately caused them to suffer damages.Â  In turn, each Respondent
  filed a motion for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations, a lack
  of material evidence to support the Turnersâ€™ causes of action, and Charlene Turnerâ€™s
  (Mrs. Turner) lack of standing as a real party in interest. Â Â 
The
  trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motions, finding the Turners â€œshould have been
  on notice of their alleged injury beginning with the premium increases in
  1998.â€Â  Because the Turners did not file suit until December 19, 2003, and
  because they â€œshould have been on notice of their alleged claims before
  December 20, 2000,â€ the trial court found their claims were barred by the
  three-year statute of limitations.Â  The trial court additionally held
  Millimanâ€™s representations to the Turners were matters of opinion or representations
  as to future events, which were not actionable in fraud or negligent
  misrepresentation cases.Â  The trial court further held that the Turnersâ€™ claim
  for a violation of SCUTPA was unsupported as SCUTPA contains an explicit
  exemption for insurance-related practices.[5]Â 
  Finally, the trial court found Mrs. Turner was not a real party in interest
  because she was not a co-insured under the group coverage policy.Â  
The
  Turners filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, which the trial court denied.Â 
  Respondents also filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the
  judgment, asserting additional sustaining grounds for the trial courtâ€™s grant
  of summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion and
  amended its order to find that Millimanâ€™s representations were not attributable
  to MidAmerica or CBA because he was not an employee or agent of the respective
  insurers.Â  Further, because MidAmerica had ceded all of its rights and
  responsibilities to Provident Indemnity, any alleged misrepresentations by
  Milliman were not attributable to MidAmerica. Â This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard
  applied by the trial court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C.
  242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The trial court should grant summary
  judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and
  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to
  a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Russell v. Wachovia
    Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 334 (2003).Â  In
  determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all
  reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the
  non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629
  S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite
  the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€ Â George
    v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001). Â Summary judgment
  is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is
  desirable to clarify the application of the law. Â Englert,
    Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc., 377
  S.C. 129, 134, 659 S.E.2d 496, 498 (2008).Â  
ISSUES ON APPEAL
The
  Turners raise four issues on appeal:
(1) The trial court erred in
  finding their claims were barred by the statute of limitations because
  conflicting evidence was presented as to when the Turners knew or should have
  known they had colorable claims against Respondents.
(2) The trial court erred in
  finding Millimanâ€™s representations to the Turners did not support an action for
  fraud or negligent misrepresentation because the statements were made as part
  of a general scheme to induce the Turners to purchase group health insurance.Â  
(3) The trial court erred in
  holding Millimanâ€™s statements were not attributable to MidAmerica or CBA
  because Milliman held himself out as an insurance agent of MidAmerica and CBA.
(4) The trial court erred in
  holding Mrs. Turner lacked standing because the contracting parties intended
  for her to be a third-party beneficiary of the insurance contract.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.Â  The Statute of
  Limitations as a Bar to Recovery 
The Turners argue
  the trial court erred in granting Respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment based
  on the statute of limitations. Â We agree.
The statute of limitations for a tort
  action is three years. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (Supp. 2007) (stating the statute of limitations for â€œan action
  for assault, battery, or any injury to the person or rights of another, not
  arising on contract and not enumerated by lawâ€ is three years). Â The
  limitations period begins to run when the facts and circumstances of an injury
  would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some claim
  against another party might exist.Â  Burgess v. Am. Cancer Socâ€™y, South
    Carolina Div., Inc., 300 S.C. 182, 186, 386 S.E.2d 798, 800 (Ct. App. 1989); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (Supp. 2007) (â€œ[A]ll actions
  initiated under Section 15-3-530(5) must be commenced within three years after
  the person knew or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known
  that he had a cause of action.â€); Epstein v. Brown, 363 S.C. 372, 376, 610
  S.E.2d 816, 818 (2005) (noting that under the discovery rule, the statute of
  limitations begins to run from the date the injured party either knows or
  should know, by the exercise of reasonable diligence, that a cause of action exists
  for the wrongful conduct).Â  The standard
  as to when the limitations period begins to run is objective rather than
  subjective.Â  Burgess, 300 S.C. at 186, 386 S.E.2d at 800. Â Moreover,
  â€œ[t]he statute is not delayed until the injured party seeks advice of counsel
  or develops a full-blown theory of recovery; instead, reasonable diligence
  requires a plaintiff to â€˜act with some promptness.â€™â€Â  Maher v. Tietex Corp.,
  331 S.C. 371, 377, 500 S.E.2d 204, 207 (Ct. App. 1998) (internal citations omitted).Â  
The
  burden of establishing the bar of the statute of limitations rests upon the one
  interposing it, and when the testimony is conflicting upon the question, it
  becomes an issue for the jury to decide.Â  Brown v. Finger, 240 S.C. 102,
  113, 124 S.E.2d 781, 786 (1962).Â  However, when there is no conflicting
  evidence or only one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the
  determination of when a party knew or should have known that he or she had a
  claim becomes a matter of law to be decided by the trial court.Â  See Arant
    v. Kressler, 327 S.C. 225, 229, 489 S.E.2d 206, 208 (1997) (finding the trial
  court properly denied amendment of pleadings against defendant doctor in
  medical malpractice case and properly directed a verdict for the defendants when
  no conflicting testimony was presented regarding time of discovery of
  additional cause of action such that the notice issue was one for the trial
  court to decide); Johnston v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 61, 65, 437 S.E.2d 45, 47
  (1993) (finding grant of summary judgment in medical malpractice case was
  proper based on statute of limitations because even taking the facts in the
  light most favorable to the plaintiff, only one reasonable inference existed as
  to when the plaintiff knew or should have known she had a claim).Â  
The trial court
  found that the initial premium level in November 1996 was $101.80 per month,
  which had almost doubled to $194.50 by October 1998 and had increased over 250%
  to $266.95 by October 1999.Â  The trial court held that these increases
  â€œstanding alone were sufficient to put [the Turners] on notice that Mr. Millimanâ€™s statements about premium increases were wrong and that [the Turners]
  were being injured financially.â€Â  Because the premiums only continued to
  increase, the trial court reasoned the Turners should have been on notice
  beginning with the premium increases in 1998 but no later than the cutoff date
  of December 19, 2000.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to
  the Turners, there is more than one reasonable inference as to when the Turners
  knew or should have known they had a claim against Respondents.Â  Although the
  dates and amounts of the premium increases are undisputed, we believe a genuine
  issue of material fact exists as to when the Turners were on notice that
  Millimanâ€™s prior representations were inconsistent with the premium increases.Â 
  The premiums increased significantly between 1998 and 2000, but the Turners
  argue that it was not until May 30, 2001, when they received notification that the
  premium would increase to $799.61, that they were on notice of a potential
  claim.Â  While Turner conceded he expected the premiums to increase, he stated that
  by the end of June 2001, he was aware the premium increases were unreasonable. Â Upon
  receiving the last premium increase notification, the Turners promptly
  investigated the premium increases by corresponding with the South Carolina Department
  of Insurance in an attempt to ascertain why the premiums were increasing so
  drastically.Â  Further, Mrs. Turner stated in a 2003 letter to the Delaware
  Department of Insurance that â€œsoaring premiumsâ€ were not a concern until 2001.Â  
While
  Respondents allege only one reasonable inference can be drawn from the
  evidence, based on the varying amounts of the premium increases and the timing
  of those premium increases, we believe reasonable minds could differ on this
  issue.Â  See Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 445, 415 S.E.2d 796,
  799 (1992) (stating summary judgment is appropriate when â€œplain, palpable, and
  indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differâ€). Â The
  determination of when the Turners knew or should have known of any potential
  claims was consequently a jury issue.Â  See Santee Portland Cement Co.
    v. Daniel Intâ€™l Corp., 299 S.C. 269, 274, 384 S.E.2d 693, 696 (1989); overruled
      on other grounds by Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l
        Vendors Div. Of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 462 S.E.2d 858 (1995)
  (finding that when all of the evidence goes to the reasonableness of a partyâ€™s
  actions, the statute of limitations issue becomes one for the jury to decide). Â As
  such, the trial court improperly granted Respondentsâ€™ motions for summary
  judgment based on the expiration of the statute of limitations. 
II. Millimanâ€™s Statements
  as a Basis for Fraud or Negligent Misrepresentation Claims
The Turners
  next contend that the trial court erred in finding Millimanâ€™s representations
  to the Turners did not support an action for fraud or negligent
  misrepresentation because the statements were made as part of a general scheme
  to induce the Turners to purchase group health insurance.Â  We disagree. 
A plaintiff
  asserting a claim for fraud in the inducement to enter into a contract must
  establish by clear and convincing evidence the following:

	(1) a
  representation, (2) its falsity, (3) its materiality, (4) knowledge of its
  falsity or reckless disregard of its truth or falsity, (5) intent that the
  representation be acted upon, (6) the plaintiffâ€™s ignorance of its falsity, (7)
  the plaintiffâ€™s reliance on its truth, (8) the plaintiffâ€™s right to rely
  thereon, and (9) the plaintiffâ€™s consequent and proximate injury. 

M.B. Kahn Constr. Co. v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank of Charleston, 275 S.C. 381, 384, 271 S.E.2d 414, 415 (1980).Â  Clear
  and convincing evidence is the â€œdegree of proof which will produce in the mind
  of the trier of facts a firm belief as to the allegations sought to be
  established.â€ Â Peeler v. Spartan Radiocasting, Inc., 324 S.C. 261, 265
  n.4, 478 S.E.2d 282, 284 n.4 (1996).Â  In such a case as this, fraud â€œmust be established by evidence which is clear, definite,
  unequivocal, and satisfactory, or such, as has been said, as to lead to but one
  conclusion, or as to leave no reasonable doubtâ€ as to the conclusion to be
  drawn.Â  All v. Prillaman, 200
  S.C. 279, 304, 20 S.E.2d 741, 750 (1942)
  (specifying the standard of proof to establish a constructive trust as a result
  of partyâ€™s fraudulent actions). 
A plaintiff
  in a negligent misrepresentation action must establish by a preponderance of
  the evidence the following:

	(1) the
  defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff, (2) the defendant had a
  pecuniary interest in making the statement, (3) the defendant owed a duty of
  care to see that he communicated truthful information to the plaintiff, (4) the
  defendant breached that duty by failing to exercise due care, (5) the plaintiff
  justifiably relied on the representation, and (6) the plaintiff suffered a
  pecuniary loss as the proximate result of his reliance on the representation. 
	

McLaughlin v. Williams, 379 S.C. 451, 456, 665 S.E.2d 667, 670 (Ct. App. 2008).Â 
  A key difference between fraud and negligent misrepresentation is that fraud
  requires the conveyance of a known falsity, while negligent misrepresentation
  is predicated upon transmission of a negligently made false statement. Â See Gruber v. Santee Frozen Foods, Inc., 309 S.C. 13, 20, 419 S.E.2d 795,
  799 (Ct. App. 1992). 
Under
  either cause of action, the failure to prove any one of the required elements
  is fatal to the claim. Â Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 41, 557 S.E.2d
  676, 680 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Generally, for a representation to be actionable, it
  must relate to a present or pre-existing fact rather than a statement of future
  events or an unfulfilled promise. Â Id. at 41-42, 557 S.E.2d at 680.Â  Further,
  sales talk or â€œpuffingâ€ ordinarily is not sufficient to establish a claim for
  negligent misrepresentation or fraud.Â  Jones v. Cooper, 234 S.C. 477, 487,
  109 S.E.2d 5, 10 (1959); Satcher v. Berry, 299 S.C. 381, 383, 385 S.E.2d
  41, 42 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  An exception to the general rule is recognized for
  unfulfilled promises which were made by a party who never intended to fulfill
  the promise and only made the promise to induce the performance of another
  party.Â  Brown, 348 S.C. at 42, 557 S.E.2d at 680.Â  
Viewing the facts
  in the light most favorable to the Turners, even if Milliman made the alleged
  statements to the Turners, these representations are not actionable as a matter
  of law as they cannot be construed as more than Millimanâ€™s opinion as to future
  events.Â  Turner acknowledged that Millimanâ€™s statements about the policy being
  the â€œbest group insurance product he had ever seen or offered for saleâ€ was
  only Millimanâ€™s opinion.Â  Further, when questioned as to whether Turner thought
  Milliman was lying to him when Milliman told Turner the premiums would not
  drastically increase, Turner responded â€œnoâ€ and agreed that he thought Milliman
  was giving Turner his honest and informed belief at that time.Â  With respect to
  the remaining representations by Milliman, Turner acknowledged that these
  statements related to future events.Â  Because mere unfulfilled promises or
  statements as to future events are not actionable, and because no evidence was
  presented to show Milliman made those statements only to induce the Turners
  into procuring the policy, the trial court properly granted Respondentsâ€™
  summary judgment motions on this ground.[6] Â See Woods v. State, 314 S.C. 501, 506, 431 S.E.2d 260, 263 (Ct.
  App. 1993) (stating the failure to observe a promise may support an inference
  of fraud or a lack of intent to perform only when the failure is coupled with
  other evidence). 
CONCLUSION
Even
  though we disagree with the trial courtâ€™s finding that the statute of
  limitations expired as a matter of law, we nevertheless affirm its decision to
  grant summary judgment based on the nature of Millimanâ€™s statements to the
  Turners.Â  Because the Turnersâ€™ action for fraud and negligent misrepresentation
  against Respondents hinges on Millimanâ€™s representations, which are not
  actionable as a matter of law, the trial court properly granted summary
  judgment in favor of Respondents.Â  
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED. 
WILLIAMS
  and PIEPER, JJ., concur. Â Â Â Â 


[1] Respondents argue Milliman is a general insurance
  broker rather than an insurance agent.Â  For purposes of this appeal, we
  generally refer to Milliman as an â€œinsurance agentâ€ but express no opinion as
  to whether Milliman is an agent or broker, as reaching a conclusion in this
  regard is not necessary for the disposition of this case.
[2] CBA notified Turner in April 1997 that Turnerâ€™s
  policy with MidAmerica would be terminated and assumed in May 1997 by Provident
  American.Â  
[3] To obtain group health insurance through CBA, Turner
  had to join CBA as a member.Â  
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 39-5-10 to -170. 
[5] The Turners do not appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling on
  this issue.
[6] Due to the disposition of this issue, we need not
  address the remaining issues on appeal.Â  See Futch v. McAllister
    Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999)
  (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its
  determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal); Barr v. City
    of Rock Hill, 330 S.C. 640, 646 n.3, 500 S.E.2d 157, 160 n.3 (Ct. App. 1998)
  (affirming grant of summary judgment on the expiration of the statute of
  limitations and declining to address the appellantsâ€™ remaining arguments on the
  trial courtâ€™s alternate grounds for granting summary judgment).

title: State v. Muquit
description: Muquit appeals his convictions and sentences, arguing the circuit court erred in admitting into evidence clothing seized from his personal effects following his arrest.
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Yahya Muquit, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg   County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit
  Court Judge
Opinion No. 4479
Submitted
  November 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January 12, 2009
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Eleanor Duffy Cleary of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry
  Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General
  Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of
  Spartanburg, for Respondent.Â  
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Yahya Muquit
  (Muquit) was tried and found guilty of (1) two counts of armed robbery, (2) 
two counts of possession of a firearm during a violent crime, and (3) two counts 
of pointing and presenting a firearm.  He was sentenced to thirty-five 
yearsâ€™ imprisonment.  Muquit appeals his
    convictions and sentences, arguing the circuit court erred in admitting into
    evidence clothing seized from his personal effects following his arrest.Â 
  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
On
  October 6, 2005, two men robbed Daleâ€™s Quick Stop, a Spartanburg convenience
  store, at gunpoint.Â  A woman assisted the men by acting as a lookout. Â The participants
  absconded with approximately $1300.00.Â  Shortly after the robbery, two men and
  a woman accosted a satellite dish installer and, pointing a gun at him,
  demanded the keys to his company vehicle.Â  The keys were in the ignition, and
  the trio took the van.Â  Both victims called the police.Â  A short time later,
  the trio abandoned the van and ran away on foot.Â  After a brief chase, police
  officers apprehended Tunisha Jeter (Jeter), Hardy Lassiter (Lassiter), and
  Muquit.Â  Jeter later testified on behalf of the State and pled guilty to
  accessory after the fact of armed robbery.
Following Muquitâ€™s arrest, officers obtained a search warrant.Â  The warrant indicated in
  its description Muquit was the person to be searched and the clothes he was
  wearing during the commission of the robbery were to be seized if found.Â 
  However, at the time the warrant was issued and executed, Muquit was in a
  detention center wearing jail-issued clothing.Â  The clothing sought in the
  warrant had been removed and stored in a separate location at the jail.Â  The
  officers seized the stored clothing from the detention center to use as
  evidence.Â  
At
  trial, Muquit and Lassiter sought to suppress the clothing seized from their
  personal effects while they were in jail.Â  The circuit court denied their
  motion and allowed the clothing into evidence over objections from both
  defendants.Â  The trial judge instructed:Â  

	In any event, I donâ€™t have any question
  that these search warrants are invalid . . . .Â  It described the person to be searched
  and that person was not searched.Â  Items that have been seized were seized from
  some other location that was not described in this warrant.Â  
	So any search or any seizure of property
  canâ€™t be predicated upon the validity of these warrants because these warrants
  donâ€™t authorize anybody to search the location where the property was taken.Â 
  But itâ€™s my view that in this particular case under the facts of it the search
  warrant was unnecessary, that the seizure was appropriate; and so I am going to
  deny each of the defendantsâ€™ motions to suppress based upon the invalidity of
  the search warrant, and they are.Â  But they werenâ€™t necessary, I donâ€™t believe,
  in order for the seizure to take place.Â  

Both
  Muquit and his co-defendant were convicted on all charges.Â  
ISSUE
Did the trial
  judge err by refusing to suppress evidence seized during a warrantless search
  of property in the custody of the detention center where the owner of the
  property was being incarcerated?
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court
  sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388,
  577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s
  factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id., 577 S.E.2d at
  500-501.Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings
  in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Id.Â  Our review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited to
  determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.Â  State
    v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 501, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005); see also State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48-49, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006)
  (â€œThe trial judgeâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed
  due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed for clear error.â€).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Muquit contends the circuit court erred
  in admitting into evidence clothing seized from his personal effects following
  his arrest.Â  We disagree.Â  
Although there is no South Carolina case
  law directly on point, the federal courts view the issue of seizing property
  already in custody as well-settled.Â  Authority to search an arrestee derives
  not only from the need to disarm him, but also from â€œthe need to preserve
  evidence on his person for later use at trial.â€ Â U.S. v. Robinson, 414 U.S. 218, 234 (1973) (citing Agnello v. U.S., 269 U.S. 20 (1925); Abel v. U.S.,
  362 U.S. 217 (1960)).Â  When an arresteeâ€™s property is already in the custody of
  law enforcement as an incident of the arrest, the police may seize it at a
  later time as evidence relating to his offense.Â  U.S. v. Edwards, 415 U.S. 800, 806-807 (1974) (citing Cooper v. California, 386 U.S. 58, 61-62 (1967)) (holding
  seizure of arresteeâ€™s car impounded incidental to arrest was proper even though
  it occurred a week after arrest).Â  In Edwards, the United States Supreme
  Court enunciated:Â  

	[O]nce the accused is lawfully arrested
  and is in custody, the effects in his possession at the place of detention that
  were subject to search at the time and place of his arrest may lawfully be
  searched and seized without a warrant even though a substantial period of time
  has elapsed between the arrest and subsequent administrative processing, on the
  one hand, and the taking of the property for use as evidence, on the other. This
    is true where the clothing or effects are immediately seized upon arrival at
    the jail, held under the defendant's name in the â€˜property roomâ€™ of the jail,
    and at a later time searched and taken for use at the subsequent criminal trial. Â The result is the same where the property is
  not physically taken from the defendant until sometime after his incarceration.Â  
	

Id. at 807-808 (emphasis added) (footnotes
  omitted).Â  
Muquit argues the seizure of his
  clothing was not incident to his arrest, relying on Chimel v. California,
  395 U.S. 752, 764 (1969).Â  However, Chimel did not contemplate a search
  or seizure of property already in the custody of law enforcement.Â  Instead, Chimel restricts arresting officers from conducting a warrantless search of an
  arresteeâ€™s home, rather than the immediate area around him where he may have hidden
  a weapon or evidence against him, for evidence of a crime.Â  Id. at 768.Â 
  Muquit further argues he had a â€œreasonable expectation of privacy in the
  contents of [his] personal effects secured by the jail.â€Â  However, a personâ€™s
  expectation of privacy is either greatly diminished or nonexistent when he is
  arrested and transfers custody of his property to the State.Â  See Edwards,
  415 U.S. at 806-807.Â  Indeed, once the police acquired custody of Muquitâ€™s
  personal effects, they had authority to search or seize that property for use
  as evidence in prosecuting the crime for which he was arrested.Â  Consequently,
  the seizure of Muquitâ€™s clothing was proper, and the circuit court did not err
  in admitting the clothing into evidence.Â  
CONCLUSION
On
  this novel issue, we hold that the seizure of an incarcerated defendantâ€™s
  personal effects in his possession or the possession of the detention center or
  jail where he is being held is not a violation of the Fourth Amendment of the
  United States Constitution.Â  Accordingly, we 
AFFIRM.
HUFF and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Moore v. Barony House Restaurant
description: In this products liability case concerning used golf cars, Moore and Stroud, as personal representatives of the estate of Brandon Stroud, appeal the granting of summary judgment to Textron, Inc., doing business as E-Z-Go Golf Cars.  We affirm finding the dangers posed by driving an unlighted golf car on a public highway at night are open and obvious thereby precluding plaintiffs' strict liability and negligence claims.
