THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Chastity
          Chastain, Appellant,
        v.
        Tyson Chastain, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
  Â Arthur E. Morehead, III, Family Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  4484
  Heard December 11, 2008 â€“ Filed January
12, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Irby E. Walker, Jr., and G. Miles Gordon, both of Conway, for Appellant.
        Marian D. Nettles, of Lake City and Kevin M. Barth, of Florence, for Respondent.
        Philip Bryan Atkinson, of Florence as Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  
Chastity Chastain (Wife)
  appeals from an order of the family court awarding custody of her three
  children to Tyson Chastain (Husband) and requiring her to pay $2,500 in private
  investigator fees.Â  Wife alleges, inter alia, that the family court
  judge erred in holding she engaged in flagrant promiscuity.Â  We disagree with
  the family courtâ€™s holding as to flagrant promiscuity but affirm the underlying
  action.
FACTS
Husband and Wife
  married on March 9, 1996.Â  They lived in Columbia until the birth of their
  first child, Cassidy, on July 15, 1997.Â  After Cassidy was born, they moved to
  Johnsonville where they lived with Husbandâ€™s parents for several months before
  they began renting their own home.Â  Later that same year, Husband and Wife
  separated, and Husband moved back in with his parents while Wife, along with
  Cassidy, moved into a double-wide trailer in Lake City.Â  After four or five
  months of separation, Husband and Wife resolved their marital differences, and
  Husband moved into the trailer in Lake City with his wife and daughter.Â 
  However, when Cassidy became old enough to attend school, Husband and Cassidy
  stayed at Husbandâ€™s parentsâ€™ home in Johnsonville during the week so Cassidy
  could attend school in the Johnsonville School District.Â  During the remainder
  of their marriage, Husband and Wife had two children:Â  Dawson, born December 3,
  2001, and Elizabeth Grace, born December 8, 2003.Â  
During the time
  they lived in Columbia, Husband played professional golf and worked as an
  assistant golf professional.Â  After moving to Johnsonville in 1997, Husband
  continued working as an assistant golf pro in Florence.Â  However, Husband was
  fired for stealing $5,000 from the golf club.[1]Â 
  After losing his job, Husband began working as the office manager for a
  construction company, ASI.Â  When Husband began working for ASI, the company was
  owned by Wifeâ€™s uncle.Â  While ASI was owned by Wifeâ€™s uncle, Husband was
  required to work long hours and commute to the companyâ€™s office in Florence.Â  In 2003, Husbandâ€™s father purchased ASI and moved the companyâ€™s office to a
  spare room located in his home in Johnsonville.Â  Currently, Husband works for
  ASI out of his parentsâ€™ home and enjoys a very flexible work schedule.Â 
  Meanwhile, Wife has maintained employment as an administrative assistant at Nan
  Ya Plastics since she moved to the Johnsonville area.Â  
Early in 2005,
  Husband suspected Wife was having an extramarital affair, and he hired a
  private investigator, Alan Capps, to confirm his suspicions.[2]Â 
  Capps reported Wife was having an affair with a co-worker, Steve Vargas.Â 
  Thereafter, Husband commenced a divorce action on the grounds of adultery.Â 
  However, the family court dismissed the action based on condonation, finding
  Husband and Wife engaged in sexual relations before the hearing.Â  According to
  Husband, Wife offered him little help with the children during this time and
  spent her nights talking on the telephone and away from the house.Â  On July 13,
  2005, Husband left the marital home and took the children to his parentsâ€™
  house.Â  The parties have been separated since that time, and, on August 1,
  Husband commenced this action for divorce, custody, child support, and separate
  support and maintenance.Â  In October 2005, Wife began an extramarital affair
  with another co-worker, Lee Dotson.[3]Â  
While the parties
  were separated, Wife brought Dotson to Cassidyâ€™s dance recital.Â  After the
  dance recital, Wife, along with Dotson, approached Husband and asked where the
  children were.Â  Husband, who had already sent the children home with his
  brother, responded by telling Dotson to step outside and that he was going â€œto
  beat his tail.â€ Â Wife and Leeâ€™s parents followed the men outside.Â  While
  outside, Husbandâ€™s mother attempted to take a picture of Wife and Dotson
  together.Â  Wife pushed Husbandâ€™s mother away from her to prevent her from
  taking the picture.Â  In turn, Husband grabbed Wife by the arm.Â  A physical
  altercation ensued between Husband and Dotson, ending with the arrest of
  Husband, his mother, Wife, and Dotson.Â  All eventually pled guilty to
  disorderly conduct and paid fines.Â  
This would not be
  the last incident between Husband, Wife, and Dotson.Â  After Husband and Wife
  had been separated for eight months, Husband began having sexual relations with
  Dotsonâ€™s wife, Beth.[4]Â 
  One night, Dotson and Wife followed Husband and Beth from Ruby Tuesdayâ€™s to
  Bethâ€™s house.Â  When they arrived at Bethâ€™s house, Dotson peered in the window
  and observed Husband and Beth kissing.Â  After a few moments of deliberation
  with Wife, Dotson threw a brick through the bedroom window.Â  Then, Dotson and
  Wife kicked the door of the residence open.Â  While inside, Dotson and Wife took
  pictures of Husband as he put his clothes on and of Beth with the bed-covers
  pulled over her.Â  
In spite of Wifeâ€™s
  on-going relationship with Dotson, she claims he has had no interaction with
  her children.Â  She admits he stayed at her house one night while the children
  were in her care.Â  However, Wife maintains the children were asleep and did not
  see Dotson.Â  
The
  Guardian ad Litem, Phillip Atkinson, visited both parents and prepared a report
  prior to the court hearing.Â  At Wifeâ€™s home, the guardian found an exposed
  light socket.Â  Furthermore, he noted Wife placed her four-year-old, Dawson, in
  the front seat without a booster seat.Â  Generally, the Guardian acknowledged
  Wife experienced difficulty controlling the children during his visit.Â  By
  contrast, the Guardian observed â€œcompletely different childrenâ€ when he visited
  Husbandâ€™s house.Â  In Husbandâ€™s home, the Guardian found the children to be
  â€œquiet, respectful, and loving.â€Â  In addition, the Guardian found Husband took
  every safety precaution imaginable in his home.Â  
The family court
  found Husband was not entitled to a divorce based on the fault grounds of
  adultery because he engaged in a sexual relationship with Dotsonâ€™s wife before
  the grant of a divorce.Â  The court, however, granted the parties a divorce on
  the grounds of living separate and apart for one year.Â  The court awarded Husband
  custody of all three children, finding Wife engaged in â€œflagrant promiscuity.â€Â 
  However, the family court found Wifeâ€™s extra-marital affairs did not negatively
  affect the welfare of her children.Â  Finally, the court directed Wife to pay
  $2,500 of Husbandâ€™s $2,700 private investigator bill, stating her adulterous
  conduct forced Husband to incur these expenses.Â  Wife did not make any
  post-trial motions and timely served her notice of appeal.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the
  family court, this court has jurisdiction to correct errors of law and find
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â Mr.
    T v. Ms. T, 378 S.C. 127, 131-32, 662 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  Although
  this court may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance
  of the evidence, we are not required to ignore the fact that the trial judge,
  who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their
  credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Marquez v.
    Caudill, 376 S.C. 229, 239, 656 S.E.2d 737, 742 (2008).Â  In particular, an
  appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the
  evidence on child custody for that
  of the [family] court.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d
  154, 157 (1996).Â Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife argues the family court erred in finding she
  engaged in flagrant promiscuity and in considering her adulterous conduct in
  determining the best interests of the children.Â  Initially, Wife notes the
  family court found her adulterous affairs did not affect her children.Â  In
  light of this finding, the only way her adulterous affairs could have been
  relevant in the best interest analysis was if the court found she engaged in
  flagrant promiscuity.Â  Wife alleges her conduct was not analogous to the
  conduct of the mother in Boykin v. Boykin, and therefore, the trial
  court committed an error of law in finding her conduct rose to the level of
  flagrant promiscuity.Â  296 S.C. 100, 370 S.E.2d 884 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Unlike
  the mother in Boykin, who engaged in five extra-marital affairs, Wife
  was only involved in two extra-marital affairs, while her Husband was involved
  in one.Â  Id. at 102, 370 S.E.2d at 886.Â  Furthermore, the mother in Boykin regularly partied with friends until the early morning hours.Â  Id.Â  Wife asserts her conduct did not rise to this level; therefore, the family
  court erred when it found she engaged in flagrant promiscuity.Â Â Â Â  
A parentâ€™s morality, while a proper consideration in
  custody disputes, is limited in its force and effect to the relevance it has,
  either directly or indirectly, on the welfare of the child.Â  Clear v. Clear,
  331 S.C. 186, 190, 500 S.E.2d 790, 792 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing Davenport v.
    Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975)).Â  Thus, conduct that
  is immoral must also be shown to be detrimental to the welfare of a child
  before it is of legal significance in a custody dispute.Â  Stroman v.
    Williams, 291 S.C. 376, 379, 353 S.E.2d 704, 705 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  However,
  flagrant promiscuity inevitably affects the welfare of the child and
  establishes â€œa watershed in the courtâ€™s quest to protect the best interests of
  a minor child.â€Â  Boykin, 296 S.C. at 102, 370 S.E.2d at 886.Â Â  
We believe the
  family court erred in finding Wifeâ€™s conduct rose to the level of flagrant
  promiscuity.Â  Flagrant promiscuity serves only as an exception to the general
  rule, which requires immoral conduct to have a detrimental affect on the
  welfare of the child in order to have legal significance.Â  Id.Â  Because
  it only exists as an exception, we believe it is meant to be invoked
  sparinglyâ€”to embrace that rare situation of glaringly bad and outrageous
  conduct not present in these facts.Â  Here, Wife engaged in two extra-marital
  affairs, while Husband engaged in one extra-marital affair.Â  In addition, Wife
  essentially lives with her current boyfriend, Dotson, when her children are not
  in her care.Â  Also, Wife brought Dotson to her daughterâ€™s dance recital, and a physical
  altercation between Dotson and Husband ensued.Â  In our view, these facts do not
  fall within the ambit of flagrant promiscuity.Â  
Accordingly,
  the family court erred in finding Wifeâ€™s conduct rose to the level of flagrant
  promiscuity.Â  Because the family court found Wifeâ€™s immoral conduct did not
  detrimentally affect the welfare of her children and because her conduct does
  not fall within the flagrant promiscuity exception, the family court also erred
  in considering her adulterous conduct in the best interests of the child
  calculus.Â  We now turn to whether the family courtâ€™s award of custody to
  Husband was in the best interests of the children.Â Â  
Wife contends the
  family court erred in awarding custody to Husband.Â  Wife claims the best
  interests of the children would have been served by granting custody to her.Â 
  Specifically, Wife asserts she, unlike Husband, regularly takes the children to
  church.Â  Moreover, she served as the primary care-taker of the children during
  their marriage while Husband spent his time playing golf.Â  
â€œThe
  paramount and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interests
  of the child.â€Â  Brown v. Brown, 362 S.C. 85, 90, 606 S.E.2d 785, 788
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The family court must consider the character, fitness,
  attitude, and inclinations on the part of each parent as they impact on the
  child.Â  Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886
  (1994).Â  Psychological, physical, environmental, spiritual, educational,
  medical, family, emotional, and recreational aspects of the childâ€™s life should
  also be considered.Â  Wheeler v. Gill, 307 S.C. 94, 99, 413 S.E.2d 860,
  863 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œIn other words, the totality of circumstances unique to
  each particular case constitutes the only scale upon which the ultimate
  decision can be weighed.â€Â  Paparella v. Paparella, 340 S.C. 186, 189,
  531 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
The best interests
  of the children are served by awarding custody to Husband, without considering
  Wifeâ€™s immoral conduct.Â  First, the family court found Wife exposed her
  children to safety risks while they were in her care.Â  Specifically, Wife
  transported her four-year-old, Dawson, in the front seat without a booster seat
  and had an exposed electrical socket in her home.Â  Second, both Husband and
  Wife agree Johnsonville School District, where Husband lives, offers a better
  education for their children than Lake City School District, where Wife lives.Â 
  In fact, while the parties were married and living in Lake City, Husband and
  Cassidy, the only child old enough to attend school, stayed at Husbandâ€™s
  parentsâ€™ home during the week so she could attend school in Johnsonville.Â  By
  awarding custody to Husband, the children can attend school in this more
  desirable school district.Â  See Glanton v. Glanton, 314 S.C. 58,
  60, 443 S.E.2d 810, 812 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œThe education of a child is something
  that affects his best interest.â€).Â  
The
  Guardian found Wife experienced difficulty controlling the children while in
  her care.Â  During the Guardianâ€™s visit to her home, only two childrenâ€”Elizabeth
  Grace and Dawsonâ€”were present.Â  Elizabeth Grace repeatedly screamed and cried
  when denied her way and refused to listen to Wifeâ€™s request to apologize to her
  brother.Â  In spite of her refusal to listen to her mother, Wife allowed
  Elizabeth Grace to continue playing without consequence.Â  By contrast, Wife
  spanked Dawson and sent him to timeout for pushing Elizabeth Graceâ€™s bike.Â  The
  inability of Wife to control her children, and the inconsistent manner in which
  she disciplined her children greatly concerned the Guardian.Â  However, the
  Guardian observed completely different children in the care of Husband.Â  While
  in his care, the children were â€œquiet, respectful, and loving.â€Â  The fact
  Husband exhibits more control over the children and instills discipline in
  their lives impacts the best interests of the child analysis.Â  See Paparella,
  340 S.C. at 189, 531 S.E.2d at 299 (noting the totality of the circumstances is
  the only way to determine the best interests of the children).Â  Â Â Â 
In addition, Husband
  works from home and maintains a flexible work schedule, which allows him to
  spend more time with the children and adjust his schedule to accommodate their
  needs.Â  Also, Husband lives with his mother, who is retired and willing to do
  whatever necessary to help in raising the children.Â  By contrast, Wifeâ€™s work
  schedule is very inflexible, and she has no one living with her in the house to
  help in raising the children.Â  Lastly, while Wife served as the primary
  caretaker of the children for a large part of their marriage, Husband has
  changed very much since this early stage of their marriage and now freely fills
  these roles.Â  As Wife stated, â€œHe wants to be daddy of the year.â€Â  â€œHe doesnâ€™t
  play golf anymore.Â  He doesnâ€™t do anything.â€Â  In addition, Wife acknowledged,
  since the separation, Husband cooks, cleans, and bathes the children.Â  In
  considering all of the factors in this case, the best interests of the children
  are served by awarding custody to Husband.Â  
 For the final issue
  on appeal, we must consider whether the family court abused its discretion in
  ordering Wife to pay $2,500 in private investigator fees to Husband.Â  Wife
  argues Husband sought a divorce on the grounds of adultery.Â  However, the
  family court refused to grant a divorce on this basis because he also engaged
  in an extra-marital affair.Â  Specifically, the family court found the
  affirmative defense of recrimination barred the grant of a divorce based on
  adultery in this case.Â  Ultimately, the court ordered Wife to pay the private
  investigator fees because her flagrant adulterous conduct caused Husband to
  incur these expenses.Â  
Section
  20-3-120 of the South Carolina Code (1976 & Supp. 2007) authorizes the
  family court to order payment of litigation expenses, including attorneyâ€™s
  fees, to either party in a divorce action.Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests
  within the sound discretion of the trial court and should not be disturbed on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â Doe v. Doe, 319 S.C. 151, 157,
  459 S.E.2d 892, 896 (Ct. App. 1995). Â The family court is given broad
  discretion in this area. Â Id.Â  â€œThe same considerations that apply to
  awarding attorneyâ€™s fees also apply to awarding litigation expenses.â€Â  Patel
    v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004) (citing Nienow
      v. Nienow, 268 S.C. 161, 173, 232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977)).Â  Reimbursable
  expenses include reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in obtaining
  evidence of a spouseâ€™s infidelity. Â Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C.
  412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).
This
  issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Iâ€™On v. Town of Mt.
    Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (noting an
  appellate court can affirm for any reason appearing in the record).Â  Wife never
  objected to the family courtâ€™s award of private investigator fees to Husband at
  trial or in a post-trial motion.Â  See Washington v. Washington,
  308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (stating issues not raised to the
  family court during trial or through post-trial motions are not preserved for
  appellate review).Â  As a consequence, this issue is not preserved for
  appeal.Â Â Â  
Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED.
SHORT,
  J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] Husbandâ€™s parents re-paid this money to his
employer.Â  
[2] Husband paid Capps and Allied Services, another
private investigator, a total of $2,700.Â  
[3] Wife and Leeâ€™s relationship was ongoing at the time
of this action.Â  
[4] Lee and his wife were separated, but not yet
divorced, at this time.Â

title: Oakwood Landfill, Inc. v. South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
description: Oakwood Landfill, Inc. and Hickory Hill Landfill appeal two orders of the South Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control affirming a landfill permit issued to T & T Disposal, LLC by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Oakwood
          Landfill, Inc. and Hickory Hill Landfill, Inc., 
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Health and Environmental Control and T & T Disposal, LLC, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From the State of South Carolina
Board of Health and Environmental Control

Opinion No.Â Â  4485
  Heard October 9, 2008 â€“ Filed January 12,
2009

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James W. Potter, Leon C. Harmon and Joan W. Hartley, all of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Alex G. Shissias, John A. Hodge and Etta R. Williams, all of
          Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  Oakwood
  Landfill, Inc. (Oakwood) and Hickory Hill Landfill (Hickory Hill) appeal two
  orders of the South Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control (the Board)
  affirming a landfill permit issued to T & T Disposal, LLC (T & T) by the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  We affirm.
FACTS 

Sections
  44-96-10 to 44-96-470 of the South Carolina Code are known as the South
  Carolina Solid Waste Policy and Management Act (SWPMA). Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  44-96-10 to -470 (2002).Â  Section 44-96-80(A) of the South Carolina Code requires
  each county in the State to prepare a single county solid waste management plan
  or participate in a regional solid waste management plan.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-96-80(A) (2002).Â  Jasper County, South Carolina, elected to participate in a
  regional plan through the Low Country Council of Governments (LCCG), which
  drafted the Low Country Regional Solid Waste Management Plan (Low Country Plan)
  in 1994.Â  The Low Country Plan was endorsed by Beaufort, Colleton, Hampton, and Jasper Counties.Â  The Plan states that â€œ[b]ased on the amount of disposal
  capacity available in and around the Lowcountry there is no apparent need to
  construct new domestic or inert landfill facilities in the next 20 years.â€Â  The
  Plan also provides the â€œrequired annual reports due September 1 of each year will
  represent the extent of progress over a given year and set forth any necessary
revisions or amendments.â€
The SWPMA also provides â€œ[n]o person shall operate a solid waste
  management facility without a permit from [DHEC].â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-96-290(A) (2002).Â  Pursuant to SWPMA, on June 30, 2003, T
  & T filed a permit application with DHEC requesting
  a Construction and Demolition, and Land-Clearing Debris Landfill Permit (landfill
  permit) to construct a landfill in Jasper County. Â DHEC conducted a public hearing for the
  project on October 27, 2003, and staff notified the public the proposed
  facility would have an estimated disposal capacity of 1,819,000 cubic yards.
DHEC was required to review the application to determine, among
  other things, if the proposed facility was consistent with the Low Country Plan.[1]Â 
  The SWPMA does not specify procedures for DHEC to follow in making need and
  consistency determinations.Â  Jasper County Council notified DHEC it found the
  proposed T & T landfill to be consistent with the countyâ€™s solid waste
  management plan in letters dated October 29, 1997; May 7, 2000; September 27,
  2000; and December 16, 2003.[2]Â 
  DHEC considered the letters to be amendments to Jasper Countyâ€™s portion of the
  plan and â€œpenciled inâ€ the changes.[3]Â 
  DHEC also had minutes from the Jasper County Council meeting at which the
  county council voted favorably on the matter.Â  After examining the applicable
  county requirements, in addition to the above-mentioned documents, DHEC
  determined T & T would be able to meet the land use requirements after
  receiving the requested landfill permit.Â  Thus, on January 14, 2004, DHEC issued the landfill permit to T
  & T and stated in the permit the facility would have a final disposal
  capacity of approximately 1,819,000
  cubic yards.
On January 30, 2004, Oakwood and Hickory Hill requested a
  contested case hearing, challenging DHECâ€™s decision to issue the T & T permit.Â 
  Oakwood and Hickory Hill alleged DHECâ€™s consistency determination failed to
  meet the requirements of Section 44-96-290(F) of the South Carolina Solid Waste
  Policy and Management Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-96-290(F)
  (2002).Â  In the alternative, Oakwood and Hickory Hill argued the permit should
  be revised to limit the final disposal capacity to 2.2 million cubic feet rather
  than the 1,819,000 cubic yards approved by DHEC because Jasper Countyâ€™s Letter of Consistency called for a final disposal capacity of only 2.2 million cubic
  feet.
On March 15, 2005, the Administrative Law Court (ALC) reversed
  DHECâ€™s decision, finding the landfill was inconsistent with the Low Country Plan because the Plan had not been amended
  to allow for the T & T landfill.Â  Specifically, the ALC determined section 44-96-80(O) of the South Carolina Code required any amendments
  to the Low Country Plan to be adopted by a multi-party endorsement.[4]Â  The ALC did not make any findings on the
  capacity issue because its ruling on the consistency determination was
  dispositive.Â  
On April 14, 2005, DHEC and T & T appealed the ALCâ€™s final
  order to the Board.Â  The Board upheld DHECâ€™s issuance of the permit on March
  30, 2006.Â  The Board
  determined neither section 44-96-80(O) of
  the South Carolina Code nor the Low Country Plan placed any limitations on a
  countyâ€™s ability to amend the plan as it applied to that particular county.Â 
  The Board also remanded the
  matter to the ALC to determine the allowable maximum capacity for the landfill because
  the ALC had not made any findings on the capacity issue.
On August 28, 2006, the ALC held DHEC had properly set the permit disposal capacity at
  1,819,000 cubic yards.[5]Â 
  Oakwood and Hickory Hill appealed and on July 9, 2007, the Board affirmed the ALCâ€™s August 28, 2006 Order and affirmed DHECâ€™s decision to
  set the final disposal capacity at 1,819,000 cubic yards.Â  This appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  ALC presides over all hearings of contested DHEC permitting cases and, in such
  cases, serves as the fact-finder and is not restricted by the findings of the
  administrative agency.Â  Dorman v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control,
  350 S.C. 159, 164-65, 565 S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App. 2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-600(A)-(B) (Supp. 2007). Â â€œAn aggrieved party may appeal the ALCâ€™s
  decision to the agencyâ€™s Appellate Panel [(the Board)]; however, the Panelâ€™s
  review is confined to the record and is governed by South Carolina Code section
  1-23-610(C).â€Â  Terry v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 377
  S.C. 569, 573, 660 S.E.2d 291, 293 (Ct. App. 2008). Â â€œAccordingly, the [Board]
  can reverse the ALCâ€™s decision if it determines the ALCâ€™s findings are not
  supported by substantial evidence contained in the record or are affected by an
  error of law.â€ Â Id. at 573-74, 660 S.E.2d at 293-94; see also Grant
    v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 353, 461 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1995)
  (stating the ALCâ€™s findings are supported by substantial evidence if, looking
  at the record as a whole, there is evidence from which reasonable minds could
  reach the same conclusion as the ALC).
After
  an aggrieved party has exhausted all administrative remedies, the party is
  entitled to judicial review by the South Carolina Court of Appeals. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A) (Supp. 2007). Â Judicial review is confined to the

  the South Carolina Code.[11]Â 
  I believe a distinction based upon the posture of the proceeding and the

The
  general rule "that administrative remedies must be exhausted absent
  circumstances supporting an exception to the rule" is well established in South Carolina.Â  Hyde v. S.C. Dept. of Mental Health, 314 S.C. 207, 208, 442 S.E.2d
  582, 583 (1994).Â  At its core, the doctrine of exhaustion serves two main
  purposes: (1) the protection of administrative agency authority; and (2) the
  promotion of efficiency.Â  Woodford v. Ngo, 548 U.S. 81, 89 (2006).Â  An administrative agency's authority is protected by exhaustion
  because it gives the agency "an opportunity to correct its own mistakes
  with respect to the programs it administers before it is haled into . . .
  court, and discourages disregard of the agency's procedures."Â  Id. (internal quotation omitted).Â  Efficiency is promoted by the exhaustion doctrine
  because claims generally can be resolved more rapidly and economically by
  agency hearings and procedures than by litigation in court.Â  Id.Â 
  Moreover, "even where a controversy survives administrative review,
  exhaustion of the administrative procedure may produce a useful record for
  subsequent judicial consideration."Â  Id.
Thus, when a
  statute mandates the exhaustion of administrative remedies, the animating
  principles of (1) protection of agency authority and (2) efficiency are
  necessarily present.Â  As such, although parties to a case may decide that
  exhaustion is not efficient in a particular case, "administrative law
  creates an incentive for these parties to do what they would otherwise prefer
  not to do, namely, to give the agency a fair and full opportunity to adjudicate
  their claims"; this is achieved by "requiring proper exhaustion of
  remedies, which means using all steps that the agency holds out, and doing so properly"Â  Id.Â  In short, absent an exception, so long as there is an opportunity for
  completion and review of a matter, then the parties must avail themselves of
  the entire administrative process prior to seeking judicial relief.[12]

  Procedures Act (APA), which "purports to provide uniform procedures before
  State Boards and Commissions and for judicial review after the exhaustion of
  administrative remedies." [13]Â  Bursey v. S.C. Dep't of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 369 S.C. 176, 182, 631 S.E.2d 899, 903 (2006).Â  While the doctrine
  of exhaustion is not without exceptions, no exception has been presented herein
  nor has any reason been presented as to why review of the final agency decision
  would not provide an adequate remedy.Â  When a matter is remanded within the
  administrative process itself, that matter is essentially "in house"
  and does not lend itself well to the judicial review process until a final
  agency decision is made.Â  To some extent, the premature involvement by the
  judicial branch could ultimately impact the decision-making process the
  legislature intended to grant to the executive branch through the
  administrative process in the first instance.Â  Accordingly, I would hold the
  Appellants timely filed their appeal.

  law, an appeal is to the court of appeals."Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  We also note that this statute has been amended, effective as of
  June 16, 2008, such that Article 5 is no longer referenced.Â  See Act No.
  334, 2008 S.C. Acts 334.
[11] Section 14-3-330(1) of the South Carolina Code
  (2005), captioned "Appellate jurisdiction in law cases," references
  appealability; it includes: "any intermediate judgment, order or decree in
  a law case involving the merits in actions commenced in the court of common
  pleas and general sessions, brought there by original process or removed there
  from any inferior court or jurisdiction, and final judgments in such actions;
  provided, that if no appeal be taken until final judgment is entered the court
  may upon appeal from such final judgment review any intermediate order or
  decree necessarily affecting the judgment not before appealed from."Â  S.C.
Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(1) (2005).
[12] The statute suggests that as long as an adequate
  remedy is available upon review of the final agency decision, any preliminary,
  procedural, or intermediate agency action or ruling would be premature for
  judicial review.Â  Â§ 1-23-380(A) S.C. Code Ann. (Supp. 2007).Â  Furthermore, the
  statutory language of Section 1-23-380(A) establishes the distinction between a
  final decision and a decision that is preliminary, procedural, or intermediate
  in nature.Â  Id.Â  Even in the context of these preliminary or
  intermediate decisions, the statute does not require a party to seek immediate judicial review.Â  Id.Â  Similarly, the language of Section 1-23-610 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) also requires a final decision when
  judicial review is sought from an administrative law judge.Â  Â§ 1-23-610 S.C.
  Code Ann. (Supp. 2007) (Amended in Act No. 334, 2008 S.C. Acts 334).
[13] While a caption is not controlling, I note the
  applicable statute here is captioned "Judicial review upon exhaustion of
administrative remedies."Â  Â§ 1-23-380(A) S.C. Code Ann. (Supp. 2007).

title: South Carolina Department of Transportation v. Hood
description: In this condemnation action, the South Carolina Department of Transportation (the Department) argues the circuit court erred in admitting evidence of an option held by Fairfield County to purchase Gloria Hoodâ€™s property.  We reverse and remand.  We hold an expired and unexercised option contract is essentially an unaccepted offer; thus, the circuit court erred in admitting evidence of Fairfield Countyâ€™s option.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Appellant,
        v.
        Gloria G. Hood, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4486
  Submitted November 1, 2008 â€“ Filed January
13, 2009Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Paul Dezso de Holczer, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Creighton B. Coleman, of Winnsboro; and Robert J. Sheheen, of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, A.J.: In this condemnation action, the South
  Carolina Department of Transportation (the Department) argues the circuit court
  erred in admitting evidence of an option held by Fairfield County to purchase Gloria Hoodâ€™s property.Â  We reverse and remand.[1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 30, 2004,
  the Department filed a notice of condemnation in Fairfield County to acquire a 3.5-acre portion of Gloria Hoodâ€™s 14.2-acre tract for a highway project.Â 
  The Department subsequently filed this action to determine the value of the
  condemned property.Â  
The
  Department moved in limine to exclude evidence of prior
  unaccepted offers and unexercised options to purchase the condemned property. Â At
  trial, Hood introduced evidence of an expired unexercised option held by Fairfield County in 2001 to purchase the entire 14.2 acre tract for $426,000, amounting to
  $30,000 per acre. Â The Department objected, but the circuit held the option
  admissible. 
Hoodâ€™s
  son testified the property was worth $30,000 per acre at the time the option
  was executed, and the property had appreciated in the amount of $10,000 per
  acre. 
Ultimately, the
  jury awarded Hood a $100,000 verdict, roughly $28,500 per acre.Â  The Department
  filed motions for JNOV, new trial nisi remittitur, and,
  alternatively, for a new trial absolute and for reconsideration pursuant to
  Rule 59(e), SCRCP. Â The circuit court denied all of the Departmentâ€™s post-trial
  motions. Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission or exclusion
  of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial
  court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of
  discretion. Â Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611
  S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005). Â "An abuse of discretion
  occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support." Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. The
  Department first argues the circuit court erred in admitting evidence of the
  option held by Fairfield County because it was never exercised.Â  We agree.
 Section 28-2-340 of
  the South Carolina Eminent Domain Procedure Act (the Act) sets forth the types
  of evidence admissible in condemnation proceedings to determine the value of
  the property sought to be condemned.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-340 (Supp. 2007).Â 
  "Evidence of the price and other terms upon any sale . . . relating to
  the property or to any similar property in the vicinity . . . within a
  reasonable time of the hearing" is admissible under the Act.Â  Id. (emphasis added).
Sale is defined as
  "[t]he transfer of property for title or price."Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1337 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Option contracts are "continuing offers to sell,
  irrevocable during the option period." S.C. Elec. & Gas Co. v. Hartough,
  375 S.C. 541, 547, 654 S.E.2d 87, 90 (Ct. App. 2007) (emphasis added).Â  "[T]he
  transition of an option into a contract of purchase and sale can only be
  effected by an unqualified and unconditional acceptance of the offer in
  accordance with the terms and within the time specified in the option contract."Â  Id.
In Baynham v.
  State Highway Department of South Carolina, 181 S.C. 435, 187 S.E. 528
  (1936), our supreme court held an oral offer to purchase a filling station was
  not admissible as evidence of the value of the filling station.Â  The court
  relied on Sharp v. United States, 191 U.S. 341 (1903), and quoted the
  following from Sharp:

  Oral
    and not binding offers are so easily made and refused in a mere passing
    conversation, and under circumstances involving no responsibility on either
    side, as to cast no light upon the question of value.Â  It is frequently very
    difficult to show precisely the situation under which these offers were made.Â 
    In our judgment they do not tend to show value, and they are unsatisfactory,
    easy of fabrication, and even dangerous in their character as evidence upon
    this subject. 

Id. at 349.Â  The supreme court in Baynham also
  relied on Hine v. Manhattan Railroad Company, 30 N.E. 985, 986 (N.Y.
  Sup. 1892), holding testimony regarding unaccepted offers is inadmissible
  "because it places before the court or jury an absent personâ€™s declaration or
  opinion as to value, while depriving the adverse party the benefit of
  cross-examination."Â  Id.
The admissibility
  of an expired and unexercised option contract to prove the value of property at
  a condemnation proceeding has not been addressed in South Carolina.Â  At least
  one court, however, has likened expired and unexercised option contracts to
  unaccepted offers and concluded they are not admissible for valuation
  purposes.Â  See City of Des Peres v. Persels Pâ€™ship, 831 S.W.2d
  778, 781 (Mo. Ct. App. 1992) (excluding expired option contracts as proof of
  value in condemnation cases and stating "[a]n expired contract is effectively
  an unaccepted offer").Â  In addition, several courts, without differentiating
  between expired and unexpired option contracts, have held option contracts are
  inadmissible to prove value in condemnation cases.Â  See Depâ€™t of
    Transp. v. Cochran, 287 S.E.2d 599, 600 (Ga. Ct. App. 1981) ("In
  condemnation cases where comparable sales are offered in evidence to explain
  the value testimony of expert witnesses, it is frequently held that mere
  options and unaccepted offers to purchase or sell are inadmissible as having no
  substantial probative value."); J. William Costello Profit Sharing Trust v.
    State Roads Commâ€™n of the State Highway Admin., 556 A.2d 1102, 1104 (Md. 1989)
  (citations omitted) ("Unlike consummated and binding contracts, offers are
  inadmissible to prove the value of land because the value of an offer depends
  on too many considerations to allow it to be used as a test of the worth of
  property.Â  The same reasoning ordinarily militates against the admissibility of
  option contracts."); but see Tedesco v. Mun. Auth. of Hazle Township, 799 A.2d 931, 935 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 2002) (allowing evidence of an option
  contract to prove value in a condemnation case and noting the Pennsylvania
  Eminent Domain Code allows evidence of the price and other terms of sale in any
  "contract to sell" and an option contract is a unilateral contract to sell).Â Â Â  
Accordingly, we
  reverse the circuit court and hold an expired and unexercised option contract
  is essentially an unaccepted offer; thus, the circuit court erred in admitting
  evidence of Fairfield Countyâ€™s option.Â Â Â  
II. The
  Department also argues the option was not admissible because it was held by Fairfield County, an entity with the power of eminent domain.Â  We need not address this
  issue because we are reversing and remanding this case on other grounds.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340,
  428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (holding courts need not address remaining
  exceptions when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive of the case).
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and KONDUROS, J., concur. 

[1] We decide this
case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Chastain v. Joyner
description: In this civil case, we determine whether a realtor has a legal duty to investigate defects in property or advise its clients on matters outside its expertise.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John R.
      Chastain and Katharine Chastain, Appellants,
				v.
				John H.
      Hiltabidle, Talle G. Hiltabidle and C. Dan Joyner Company, Inc., Defendants, Of
      Whom C. Dan Joyner Company, Inc. is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â Â  4487 
Heard December 2, 2008 â€“ Filed January 22,
2009
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William H. Ehlies, II, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Samuel W. Outten and Sandi R. Wilson, both of Greenville, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.: In this action for negligence, Appellants
  argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Respondent
  because Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment was procedurally defective,
  or, in the alternative, because the trial court erred in holding a realtor does
  not have a legal duty to investigate latent defects in property or to advise
  his or her clients on matters outside the scope of his or her expertise.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
C.
  Dan Joyner Company, Inc. (Realtor) provides residential real estate services
  throughout the Greenville area.Â  Joan Herlong (Agent) is an independent
  contractor for Realtor who provides services to individuals seeking to purchase
  or sell real estate.Â  In January 2003, John H. Hiltabidle and Talle G.
  Hiltabidle (Sellers) engaged Agent in conjunction with the sale of Sellersâ€™
  residence (the Property).
Agent
  listed the Property for sale in 2003.Â  Appellants John R. Chastain and
  Katherine Chastain (Buyers) were interested in purchasing the property and
  hired Agent.[1]Â 
  Buyers submitted an offer for the Property and Sellers accepted the offer that
  same day.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code. Ann. Â§ 27-50-10 to -110 (Supp. 2008), the contract
  for sale was contingent on Sellersâ€™ completion of a form titled â€œState of South Carolina Residential Property Condition Disclosure Statementâ€ (the Disclosure).Â  According
  to the express terms of the Disclosure, it was â€œnot a warranty,â€ and it was
  â€œnot a substitute for any inspections [Buyers] may wish to obtain.â€Â  
On
  the Disclosure, Sellers responded affirmatively to two inquiries.Â  First, they
  responded â€œyesâ€ to a question that asked: â€œWater seepage, leakage, dampness or
  standing water or water intrusion from any sources in any area of the
  structure?â€Â  Sellers explained their affirmative response to this question in
  the Comments section of the Disclosure, describing two past flooding events: 


	Early 1990â€™s:
  Hurricane Hugo.Â  Some storm runoff in garage [and] laundry room due to blockage
  of culvert under Wembley Rd.Â  Action [taken]: Re-landscape to allow water to
flow toward creek.
	Fall
  2002: Major tropical storm caused major flooding [and] road damage (throughout Greenville) â€“ Very light water seepage into garage due to blockage of culvert under
  Wembley.Â  Action taken: City improved swale along Wembley Rd.Â  Project started
  to install a device to prevent blockage of culvert.
	The
  creek on [the Property] has never exceeded its banks.

Second, Sellers responded â€œyesâ€
  to a question that asked, â€œFlood hazards or that the property is in a federally
  designated flood plane [sic]?â€Â  In a handwritten note next to their â€œyesâ€
  answer, Sellers wrote, â€œGround floor above 100 [year] flood level.â€Â  
Following
  Buyersâ€™ purchase of the Property, two days of rain resulted in several inches
  of water intrusion onto the Property, causing damage to Buyersâ€™ furniture and
  to the Property itself. Â 
Buyers
  filed an initial summons and complaint alleging causes of action for negligence
  and fraud[2] against Sellers arising out of the statements in the Disclosure.Â  An amended
  complaint added Realtor as a defendant.Â  A second amended complaint added Agent
  as a defendant.Â  All defendants answered denying the allegations of the complaint.Â 
  The parties agreed to dismiss Agent as an individual defendant on the
  stipulation that, at all times relevant to this action, she was acting within
  the course and scope of her employment with Realtor.Â Â Â  
Realtor
  filed a motion for summary judgment on the negligence cause of action and
  included a written memorandum in support.Â  In the memorandum in support, Realtor
  asserted two arguments.Â  First, the Disclosure did not contain any
  substantively inaccurate or misleading information.Â  Second, Realtor did not
  have actual or constructive knowledge of the alleged inaccuracies in the
  Disclosure.Â  Buyers filed a motion in opposition to Realtorâ€™s motion for
  summary judgment and a hearing was held on Realtorâ€™s motion.Â  Following oral
  arguments, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Realtor on the
  basis that Realtor did not have a legal duty to investigate latent defects in
  properties or to advise clients on matters outside the scope of its expertise.Â  
A
  Form 4 reflecting the trial courtâ€™s decision was entered on April 24, 2007.Â  Thereafter,
  Buyers filed a Rule 59(e) motion in which they argued the trial court did not
  issue a detailed order reflecting its findings of fact and conclusions of law, did
  not rule on their Rule 7(a) Due Process argument, and did not comply with the
  rule that novel issues should be decided with a full and complete record.Â  The
  trial court issued a seven-page order in which it set forth the factual and
  legal basis for finding in favor of Realtor.Â  Buyers responded by filing a
  second Rule 59(e) motion, the substance of which was essentially identical to
  their previous Rule 59(e) motion.Â  This motion was denied without a hearing.Â 
  This appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary
  judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  David v.
    McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The
  trial court should grant summary judgment if the pleadings, depositions,
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the
  affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and
  that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule
  56(c), SCRCP; Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d
  329, 334 (2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist,
  the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the
  light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr.,
  368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  A court considering
  summary judgment makes neither factual determinations nor considers the merits
  of competing testimony.Â  David, 367 S.C. at 250, 626 S.E.2d at 5.Â  However,
  summary judgment is appropriate when a properly supported motion sets forth
  facts that remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.Â  Id.Â  To survive a motion for summary judgment, the non-moving party must offer some
  evidence that a genuine issue of material fact exists as to each element of the
  claim.Â  Steele v. Rogers, 306 S.C. 546, 552, 413 S.E.2d 329, 333 (Ct. App.
  1992).
LAW & ANALYSIS
1.  Due Process/Notice
Realtor
  first argues the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment should not be reversed
  on procedural grounds because Buyers failed to present their current argument,
  that Realtorâ€™s summary judgment motion did not comply with Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP,
  and Rule 56, SCRCP, to the trial court at the motion hearing or in their motion
  for reconsideration.Â  We disagree.
It
  is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an
  appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon
  by the trial court.Â  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-511,
  598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â  When an issue is raised to but not ruled upon by
  the trial court, the issue is preserved for appeal only if the party raises the
  same issue in a Rule 59(e) motion.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke,
  330 S.C. 71, 77, 497 S.E.2d 731, 734 (1998) (noting that proper use of a Rule
  59(e) motion is to preserve issues raised to but not ruled upon by the trial
  court); Walsh v. Woods, 371 S.C. 319, 325, 638 S.E.2d 85, 88 (Ct. App.
  2006) (finding issue on appeal was not preserved because the trial court did
  not rule on the issue and it was not raised in a Rule 59(e) motion).Â  
Buyers
  argued in their motion in opposition that Realtorâ€™s motion for summary judgment
  â€œshould be dismissed as violative of SCRCP 7(b) because it does not
  particularize the grounds upon which the relief is sought and therefore fails
  to provide notice to the adverse party in violation of due process
  guarantees.â€Â  Thus, the issue of Rule 7(b) was timely raised to the trial
  court.[3]Â 
  However, at no time thereafter did the trial court specifically rule on this
  issue.Â  When the issue was raised but not ruled upon, it became incumbent upon Buyers
  to raise the issue in a Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at
  77, 497 S.E.2d at 734.Â  Buyers filed not one but two Rule 59(e) motions.Â  The
  substance of these motions, which are essentially identical, is limited to the
  following arguments:

	This
  motion is made pursuant to SCRCP, Rule 59(e).Â  The grounds for the motion are
  that the courtâ€™s [order] . . . is incomplete and ambiguous, sets forth neither
  findings of fact nor conclusions of law, fails to set forth the courtâ€™s
  reasoning for its rulings, does not rule upon the plaintiffs [sic] SCRCP
    7(a) Due Process argument, is impossible to review on appeal, violates the
  rule that novel issues should be decided with a full complete record, and it
  fails to fairly set forth facts in the record that contradict the assertions
  made in the order.

(emphasis
  added).
Buyers base their
  argument to this court on Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP.[4]Â 
  In their Rule 59(e) motions to the trial court, however, Buyers asserted a
  â€œRule 7(a) Due Process argument,â€ rather than a Rule 7(b)(1) argument.[5]Â 
  In light of this apparent scrivenerâ€™s error, Realtor argues Buyers failed to
  properly present their Rule 7(b)(1) argument to the trial court and, therefore,
  may not argue the issue now.Â  We disagree.
Although Buyersâ€™
  Rule 59(e) motion is technically insufficient to preserve the issue of Rule 7(b)(1),
  this Court will not apply the rules of error preservation so rigidly as to bar
  an otherwise properly presented issue.Â  See State v. Guillebeaux,
  362 S.C. 270, 274 n.1, 607 S.E.2d 99, 101 n.1 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding although
  Guillebeauxâ€™s issue on appeal referred to a motion for mistrial instead of a
  motion for a new trial, the court treated the references to mistrial in his
  appellate brief as a scrivenerâ€™s error because the substance of the appellate
  argument focused on the failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial under
  the circumstances); State v. James, 362 S.C. 557, 562, 608 S.E.2d 455,
  458 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding although James did not use the term â€œsubstantial
  circumstantial evidenceâ€ in his motion for a directed verdict, the argument was
  properly before the court because he argued in his directed verdict motion there
  was insufficient evidence to support the elements of the charge); State v.
    Russell, 345 S.C. 128, 132, 546 S.E.2d 202, 204 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding although
  Russell did not use the exact words â€œcorpus delictiâ€ in his request for
  a directed verdict, it was clear from the argument presented in the record that
  the motion was made on this ground).Â  
In this case, Buyersâ€™
  Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, due process argument was presented and is, therefore,
  preserved for two reasons.Â  First, Buyers previously presented a Rule 7(b) due
  process argument to the trial court in their memorandum in opposition to
  summary judgment.Â  Thus, when Buyers referred to â€œthe plaintiffâ€™s Rule 7(a) Due
  Process argumentâ€ in their Rule 59(e) motions, it appears they were referring
  to their previous Rule 7(b)(1) due process argument that the trial court had
  not ruled on.Â  Second, Buyers called their Rule 7(a) argument a â€œDue Process
  argument.â€ Â Because Buyers have maintained only one due process argument in
  this case, namely the â€œparticularityâ€ requirement in Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, correcting
  the scrivenerâ€™s error in this case is warranted.Â  Â See Holroyd v.
    Requa, 361 S.C. 43, 60, 603 S.E.2d 417, 426 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œOur courts
  have corrected scrivenersâ€™ errors when warranted.â€).Â  We, therefore, find this
  issue was sufficiently raised in the Rule 59(e) motions and, thus, properly
  preserved for review.
2.  Prejudice
Realtor
  next argues, even if the court finds Buyers properly preserved the question of
  whether Realtor complied with Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, summary judgment in favor of
  Realtor should be not be reversed on procedural grounds because Buyers can show
  no prejudice from the allegedly deficient notice.Â  We agree.
As a
  general rule, a party must establish prejudice as the result of anotherâ€™s
  failure to comply with Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  See M&M Group, Inc.
    v. Holmes, 379 S.C. 468, 474, 666 S.E.2d 262, 265 (Ct. App. 2008)
  (subjecting Rule 7, SCRCP, to a prejudice analysis).Â  To demonstrate prejudice
  in a matter involving allegedly insufficient notice, an appellant must
  establish if he or she had received appropriate notice, he or she would have
  done something different, thereby affecting the decision of the trial court and
  advancing his or her case.Â  Gardner, 353 S.C. at 14, 577 S.E.2d at 197.Â  
As
  applied to this case, Buyers must demonstrate they were unable to marshal an
  effective defense in opposition to Realtorâ€™s motion for summary judgment due to
  Realtorâ€™s failure to provide sufficient notice of the particular grounds on
  which its motion was based.Â  In other words, Buyers must show that had they received
  adequate notice, they would have done something different.
Buyers
  have made no such showing.Â  A week before the hearing on Realtorâ€™s motion for
  summary judgment, Buyers filed a memorandum in opposition to Realtorâ€™s motion
  for summary judgment in which they set forth detailed legal arguments and
  factual bases for their opposition to Realtorâ€™s motion for summary judgment and
  supporting memorandum.Â  Although Buyers claim they were not put on notice of
  the particular grounds upon which Realtor sought relief, their memorandum in
  opposition addresses the very same issues upon which the trial court ultimately
  granted summary judgment in favor of Realtor, namely, whether Realtor had a
  duty to investigate latent defects or representations by a seller, and whether
  there existed questions of fact as to whether Realtor had violated the statute.Â 
  Thus, the alleged lack of notice did not prevent Buyers from marshaling a
  defense in opposition to Realtorâ€™s motion.Â  Furthermore, Buyers have failed to
  articulate any new argument or factual issue that they were unable to present
  to the trial court due to a lack of notice.Â  Their brief on appeal essentially
  mirrors their motion in opposition.Â  As such, the Buyersâ€™ argument that but for
  the lack of notice, they would have done something different, is unconvincing
  in light of the fact that they put forth the same arguments now that they did
  at the motion hearing.Â  We, therefore, hold Buyersâ€™ procedural Due Process argument
  is without merit. Â 
3.  Merits
Buyers
  argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because Realtor owed
  them a duty of reasonable care and disclosure and because questions of fact
  remain as to what Realtor knew or should have known about the flooding history
  of the Property.Â  We disagree for two reasons.Â  First, to the extent that Realtor,
  as a real estate licensee, owes Buyers a legal duty, this duty does not include
  investigating the veracity or adequacy of statements made on the Disclosure.Â 
  Second, Buyers have presented no evidence that Realtor had actual or
  constructive knowledge that the statements on the Disclosure were inaccurate or
  incomplete.
i.  Existence of a Duty
An
  essential element in a cause of action for negligence is the existence of a
  legal duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and absent such a
  duty, no actionable negligence exists.Â  Bishop v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental
    Health, 331 S.C. 79, 86, 502 S.E.2d 78, 81 (1998).Â  The determination of
  whether a duty exists in regard to the wrong alleged is a question of law for
  the court.Â  Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 355 S.C. 329, 332, 585 S.E.2d
  275, 276 (2003).Â  If no duty exists, the defendant is entitled to judgment as a
  matter of law.Â  Id.
A
  real estate licensee is â€œnot obligated to discover latent defects in property
  or to advise the agentâ€™s clients on matters outside the scope of the agentâ€™s
  real estate expertise.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-57-137(F) (Supp. 2007); see also S.C. Code Ann Â§ 27-50-80 (Supp. 2007) (stating a real estate
  licensee has no duty to inspect the onsite or offsite conditions of the
  property and any improvements).Â  Additionally, a real estate licensee is not
  liable to a purchaser if: (1) the owner provides the purchaser with a
  disclosure form that contains false, incomplete, or misleading information, and
  (2) the real estate licensee did not know or have reasonable cause to suspect
  the information was false, incomplete, or misleading.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  27-50-70 (Supp. 2007); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-57-137(F) (stating
  a real estate company is â€œnot liable to a buyer for providing the buyer with
  false or misleading information if that information was provided to the
  licensee by his client and the licensee did not know or have reasonable cause
  to suspect the information was false or incompleteâ€).Â  Taken together, these sections
  provide that a real estate licensee does not have a duty to inspect or
  investigate the physical condition of a piece of property for the purpose of
  confirming or denying statements made by a seller in a disclosure statement.Â 
  Rather, the Legislature places the duty of performing such an inspection or
  investigation squarely on the shoulders of the buyer.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 27-50-80 (â€œThis article does not limit the obligation of the purchaser
  to inspect the physical condition of the property and improvements that are the
  subject of a contract covered by this article.â€).Â  
Here,
  Buyers were put on notice by Sellersâ€™ statements in the Disclosure that the
  Property had some history of flooding.Â  To place on Realtor and other real
  estate licensees the burden of further investigating the accuracy of such
  statements would require them to have expertise in plumbing, electrical and
  construction codes.Â  Because we do not believe this was the intent of the Legislature,
  we affirm the trial court. 
ii.  Evidence of Actual or
  Constructive Knowledge
In their brief, Buyers
  present evidence from which it could be inferred that Realtor knew there was a
  history of flooding in the neighborhood of the Property prior to 2003.Â  For
  instance, Realtor represented Sellers in their purchase of the Property in
  1985, at which time the Property had already experienced roughly $10,000 worth
  of flood damage due to a 1982 flood.Â  Additionally, numerous individuals
  associated with Realtor live in the same neighborhood where the Property is
  located.Â  As such, Buyers argue because this evidence is sufficient to raise a
  question of fact as to whether Realtor knew or should have known the Property
  was prone to flooding, summary judgment was improper.
However,
  even assuming the substantive information about flooding in the Disclosure was
  inaccurate or incomplete, and further assuming Realtor knew the Property had
  flooded in the past, it would not necessarily follow that Realtor knew Sellersâ€™
  statements in the Disclosure about the Propertyâ€™s flooding history were
  inaccurate or incomplete.Â  As stated above, if the owner of a property provides
  the purchaser with a disclosure form that contains false, incomplete, or
  misleading information, the real estate licensee is not liable unless he or she
  knew or had reasonable cause to suspect the information in the disclosure form was
  false, incomplete, or misleading.Â  S.C Code Ann. Â§ 27-50-70.Â  The statute is
  concerned with whether a real estate licensee knows the statements in a
  disclosure form are false, not simply whether the licensee knows of a defect in
  the property.Â  Therefore, to survive summary judgment, Buyers must present
  evidence that raises a question of fact as to whether Realtor knew or should
  have known that the statements in the Disclosure were inaccurate.Â  See Steele,
  306 S.C. at 552, 413 S.E.2d at 333 (holding to survive a motion for summary
  judgment, the non-moving party must offer some evidence that a genuine issue of
  material fact existed as to each element of the claim).Â  
Buyers
  have not presented such evidence.Â  First, Buyers have not provided any evidence
  that Realtor knew of any inaccuracies in the Disclosure.Â  Second, Buyers stated
  under oath they were unaware of any evidence that Agent had knowledge of any
  false, incomplete or misleading information in the Disclosure.Â  John Chastain
  testified as follows:

	Q: Do
  you have any knowledge that [Agent] had any knowledge of any of these events
  described to you by your neighbors?
	A: I
  have no knowledge, no.
	Q: Do
  you have any knowledge that [Agent] had any knowledge of these alleged water
  problems which she did not disclose to you?
	A: I do
  not.
	Q: Do
  you have any knowledge that [Agent] withheld any knowledge she may have had
  regarding these water problems which she did not disclose to you?
	A: I do
  not.

Likewise,
  Katharine Chastain testified as follows:

	Q:
  Other than this conversation that you had with [Agent] regarding the Disclosure
  Statement and the trampoline that was apparently caught in a culvert, do you
  have any other evidence relating to [Agentâ€™s] alleged knowledge of flooding at
  the residence?
	A: No.
	Q:
  Sitting here today, do you have any reason to believe that [Agent] was aware at
  the time she had the conversation with you about the Disclosure Statement that
  anything other than the trampoline had caused potential flooding at the
  [Property]?
	A: No.

Agent
  also testified under oath that she had no knowledge of flooding problems within
  the neighborhood, no knowledge of water intrusion within the home purchased by Buyers
  other than the information provided by Sellers to both her and Buyers, and no
  reason to suspect or believe the information in the Disclosure completed by Sellers
  was either false, misleading, or incomplete.Â  Because Buyers presented no
  evidence Realtor or Agent knew or had reasonable cause to suspect Sellersâ€™
  statements in the Disclosure about flooding were false, misleading or
  inaccurate, the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment was proper.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
PIEPER,
J. and GEATHERS, J., concur.


[1] Sellers and Buyers
  each executed a â€œConsent to Dual Agencyâ€ agreement on January 30, 2003, thereby
  allowing Realtor to be the agent for both the buyer and the seller of the
Property.Â  
[2] Buyersâ€™ action
  for fraud was eventually dismissed on October 10, 2006.Â  Only the action for
negligence remains.
[3] Buyers did not
  allege non-compliance with Rule 56, SCRCP, in their motion in opposition or in
  their Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Accordingly, we do not address this argument on
  appeal.Â  See Lucas, 359 S.C. at 510-511, 598 S.E.2d at 715
  (holding an appellate court will not address issues raised for the first time
on appeal).
[4] Rule 7(b)(1),
  SCRCP, states: â€œAn application to the court for an order shall be by motion
  which, unless made during a hearing or trial in open court with a court
  reporter present, shall be made in writing, shall state with particularity the
  grounds therefor, and shall set forth the relief or order sought. The
  requirement of writing is fulfilled if the motion is stated in a written notice
of the hearing of the motion.â€
[5] Rule 7(a),
  SCRCP, states: â€œThere shall be a complaint and an answer; and a reply to a
  counterclaim denominated as such; an answer to a cross-claim, if the answer
  contains a cross-claim; a third-party complaint, if a person who was not an
  original party is summoned under Rule 14, and there shall be a third-party
  answer, if a third-party complaint is served. No other pleadings shall be
  allowed, except that the court may order a reply to an answer or a third-party
  answer; and there may be a reply to affirmative defenses as provided in Rule
8(c).â€

title: Pack v. SCDOT
description: In this action for workers' compensation, Appellants appeal (a) the circuit court's decision to reverse the Workers' Compensation Commission's ruling that Claimant has not suffered a brain injury; and (b) the circuit court's decision to affirm the Workers' Compensation Commission's ruling that Claimant has suffered respiratory and psychological injury.
