THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Lou Anne Pack, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Employer and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4488
  Heard November 18, 2008 â€“ Filed January
27, 2009Â Â Â  

REVERSED IN PART, AFFIRMED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Cynthia Burns Polk, of Columbia, T. McRoy Shelley, III, Rogers Townsend & Thomas, PC, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Steven Eric Goldberg, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: In this workerâ€™s compensation action, Appellants
  contest (a) the circuit courtâ€™s decision to reverse the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commissionâ€™s holding that Pack suffered no brain injury, and (b) the circuit
  courtâ€™s decision to affirm the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s holding that Respondent
  is entitled to benefits for respiratory and psychological injury.Â  We reverse
  in part, affirm in part, and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Lou
  Anne Pack (Pack) began working for the South Carolina Department of
  Transportation (the DOT) in 2000 as an assistant with the asphalt crew.Â  Pack
  later began working with the roadside herbicide application crew.Â  Her duties
  on the roadside crew included operating a truck equipped with a herbicide
  sprayer.Â  During August 2002, the air conditioning in Packâ€™s work vehicle was
  not working properly and, as a result, she began spraying herbicides from her
  truck with the windows open.Â  On or about August 18, 2002, an amount of liquid
  herbicide â€œoverflowedâ€ from the tank on her truck and she was exposed to the
  fumes.Â  Soon after this exposure, she collapsed next to her truck.Â  Pack was
  admitted to Providence Hospital on August 30, 2002, with a diagnosis of
  â€œ[p]ossible toxic reaction to weed spray, naphthalene.â€Â  Her discharge summary
  noted her â€œrenal and hepatic functions were normal, and her neurological
  symptoms and signs cleared within 24-48 hoursâ€ and â€œthere was no slurring of
  speech.â€Â  
Appellants
  commenced payment of weekly temporary total benefits but only paid twenty-seven
  dollars ($27.00) for medical treatment.Â  Packâ€™s counsel requested additional
  medical evaluation and treatment, but Appellants refused.Â  Pack sought medical
  treatment from numerous physicians at her own expense and began seeing Dr.
  Allan Lieberman, an environmental specialist,[1] and L. Randolph Waid, Ph.D., a neuropsychologlist, in May 2003.Â  
Â On
  January 26, 2005, Appellants filed a WCC Form No. 21 Stop Payment application.Â 
  After a hearing was scheduled and the parties exchanged documents for
  admission, however, Appellants withdrew their Stop Payment application.Â  Immediately
  after this withdrawal, Pack filed a WCC Form 50, seeking either an award of
  permanency for her brain, respiratory, and psychological injuries or, in the
  alternative, an award finding she had not reached maximum medical improvement
  and was entitled to reimbursement for and additional treatment by Dr. Lieberman
  and Dr. Waid.Â  Pack alleged injury to her â€œwhole body, respiratory [system],
  brain[,] allergen, [and] chemical sensitivityâ€ in connection with the August
  18, 2002 incident.Â  Appellants filed a WCC Form 51, in which they admitted Pack
  was exposed to herbicide and may have suffered transient effects but denied any
  permanent injury.Â  
The
  Single Commissioner ruled Pack had not reached maximum medical improvement,
  that she had injury â€œto her respiratory system, brain with psychological
  overlay . . . when she was exposed multiple times to pesticides and herbicides,â€
  and that Appellants should pay for continued treatment. The Appellate Panel of
  the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission), in a 2-1 decision filed
  June 19, 2006, affirmed the Single Commissionerâ€™s decision with amendments.Â  The
  majority held Packâ€™s injuries were limited to â€œher respiratory system with
  psychological overlayâ€ but did not include the brain.Â  
The
  dissenting commissioner, Commissioner Barden, held: there was no evidence of
  any respiratory injury, there was no objective evidence of any brain or â€œtoxic
  exposureâ€ injury, Pack had reached maximum medical improvement shortly after
  exposure to herbicide, and Pack had no residual permanency.Â  In support of her
  position, Commissioner Barden noted: 

  (a)
    [Packâ€™s] discharge summary from 2002 notes that her â€œrenal and hepatic
    functions were normal,â€ her â€œneurological symptoms cleared within 24-48 hours,â€
    and â€œthere was no slurring of speech;â€ (b) [Packâ€™s] claim appears to have as
    its basis her Internet research dealing with acephate; however [Packâ€™s] plasma
    and blood levels showed no signs of insecticide exposure; further, certified
    toxicologists state that any symptoms from which [Pack] suffered were not
    related to acephate; (c) Dr. Waid is not a medical doctor, and based his
    findings on tests which show that [Pack] acts as if she has a toxic
    exposure injury; (d) Dr. Lieberman simply recites the purported exposure to
    organophosphates which no objective test has shown; (e) at most, [Pack] has had
    a psychosomatic experience from her Internet research; at worst, [Pack] is
    using the workerâ€™s compensation system for purposes of secondary gain; (f) all
    the objective medical evidence, . . . which describes [Pack] as very
    articulate and organized; that she has brought in a book with multiple tabs,
    and which summarizes medical opinions from various physicians; and that she
    speaks with fluency regarding the chemicals to which she was reportedly
    exposed.

(emphasis
  in original).
Both
  parties timely appealed to the circuit court.Â  Pack argued the Commission erred
  in denying compensability for her physical brain injury, but the Commission did
  not err in affirming compensability for respiratory and psychological injuries.Â 
  Appellants argued the denial as to Packâ€™s brain injury was proper because it
  was supported by substantial evidence.Â  Appellants further contended the
  dissenting opinion was correct and the majority opinion awarding compensability
  for respiratory and psychological injuries was not supported by substantial
  evidence.Â  
As
  to the brain injury, the circuit court reversed the Commission, holding â€œthe
  only evidence contained in the record supports the original finding that [Pack]
  sustained an injury to her brainâ€ and â€œ[t]he exclusion of the brain without
  explanation is inconsistent with the medical treatment and evaluation the
  Commission ordered.â€Â  As to respiratory and psychological injury, the circuit
  court affirmed.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  The
  Commission is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is
  not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Etheredge v.
    Monsanto Co.,Â  349 S.C. 451, 454, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The
  findings of the Commission are presumed correct and will be set aside only if
  unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d
  at 306.Â  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence that,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Taylor v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles, 368 S.C. 33, 36, 627 S.E.2d 751, 752
  (Ct. App. 2006).Â  
LAW & ANALYSIS
1. Packâ€™s Estoppel Argument
As
  an initial matter, Pack argues Appellants should be estopped from denying that
  she has suffered a brain injury because in their Form 51, Appellants â€œadmit
  [Pack] was exposed to herbicide and may have suffered transient effects.â€Â 
  However, Pack has cited no legal authority to support the argument that this
  amounts to a judicially binding admission of Packâ€™s alleged injury.Â  As such,
  this argument is conclusory, and such arguments are deemed abandoned on
  appeal.Â  See Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608
  S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding party abandoned an issue on appeal
  due to failure to cite any supporting authority and making only conclusory
  arguments).
2. Brain Injury
Appellants
  argue the circuit court erred in reversing the Commissionâ€™s decision that Pack
  has not suffered a brain injury because (a) the circuit court improperly made
  its own factual determination regarding the brain injury, and (b) substantial
  evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s denial of the brain injury claim.Â  Because we
  agree with Appellants on the first point, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s ruling
  as to the brain injury.Â  However, we do not affirm the Commissionâ€™s original
  ruling because the Commissionâ€™s finding that Pack suffered injuries to the
  respiratory system with psychological overlay, standing alone, does not
  constitute a sufficient finding to warrant denial of the brain injury.Â 
  Instead, we remand the issue to the Commission to make further findings of fact
  as to the brain injury.
In
  this case, the Commission disagreed with the Single Commissionerâ€™s finding that
  Pack had suffered a brain injury.Â  Specifically, the Commission held Packâ€™s
  only injuries were â€œto her respiratory system, with psychological overlay,â€
  whereas the Single Commissioner included the brain.Â  The circuit court noted
  this difference of opinion between the Single Commissioner and the Commission
  and characterized it as a failure by the Commission to make an essential
  finding of fact, such that remand would normally be appropriate.Â  The circuit
  court found:

  The
    Decision and Order of the [Commission] included neither a finding of fact nor
    conclusion of law explaining why the brain was removed as an affected body
    part.Â  Remand is proper where the Commission has failed to make essential
    findings of fact, or the findings are so indefinite or general as to afford no
    reasonable basis upon which the appellate court can determine whether the
    findings are supported by the evidence and whether the law has been properly
    applied to the findings.Â  

(internal
  citations omitted).
The
  circuit court went on, however, to hold that remand was not appropriate in this
  case because the evidence in the record would only support a finding in
  favor of Pack on the issue of brain injury.Â  The circuit court stated:

  [H]owever,
    where the evidence is susceptible of but one reasonable inference, the question
    becomes a matter of law for the appellate court rather than the [Commission].Â  The only medical evidence contained in the record supports the
    [Single Commissionerâ€™s] original finding that [Pack] sustained an injury to the
    brain.Â  

(emphasis
  added) (internal citations omitted).
This
  was error for two reasons.Â  First, the latter holding was erroneous because
  questions of fact are decided solely by the Commission, and the court reviewing
  the Commissionâ€™s decision lacks authority to determine factual issues, except
  in jurisdictional matters.Â  Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C.
  278, 280, 461 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1995).Â  Although the circuit court correctly
  stated that when the evidence is susceptible of but one reasonable inference,
  the question becomes a matter of law, Mullinax v. Winn Dixie Stores, Inc.,
  318 S.C. 431, 437, 458 S.E.2d 76, 80 (Ct. App. 1995), the circuit court erred
  in concluding there was no medical evidence in the record that would negate
  Packâ€™s claim of a brain injury.Â  
The
  record is replete with such evidence.Â  Dr. Bill Simpson, a family medicine specialist
  at the Medical University of South Carolina, stated, â€œ[Packâ€™s] neurological
  examination is grossly intact.â€Â  Dr. Waid stated Pack was â€œ[q]uite talkative
  during the evaluation process,â€ that her â€œ[c]onversational speech was prosodic,
  fluent, of normal rate and toneâ€ and she â€œdid not demonstrate any word finding
  difficulties in conversational speech.â€Â  Dr. Gordon Early, a specialist in
  occupational medicine, noted blood tests conducted soon after Packâ€™s last alleged
  exposure revealed no evidence of any exposure to insecticide.Â  Two board
  certified toxicologists offered their opinions that there was no evidence of
  any toxic exposure to insecticide and that, at most, Pack had transient
  symptoms from herbicide exposure.Â  Dr. Robert M. Bennett, a forensic
  toxicologist, reported that any biochemical changes that occur due to the
  toxicity of acephate are relatively short-lived, typically clearing in a matter
  of days.Â  Dr. Bennet further stated, â€œNo chronic, permanent or lasting organic
  biochemical somatic or neurological changes have been shown in the medical
  literatureâ€ and thatÂ  â€œthere are no reported cases of long term health effects
  in humans due to acephate or its formulations.â€Â  Because the record contains
  conflicting evidence on the question of whether Pack suffered a brain injury,
  it was error for the circuit court to hold that the only medical evidence in
  the record supports the Single Commissionerâ€™s original finding that Pack
  sustained an injury to the brain.Â  For this reason, the circuit courtâ€™s holding
  is reversed.
Second,
  the circuit court erred to the extent that it held it was improper for the
  Commission to disagree with the findings of the Single Commissioner.Â  The
  Commission is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is
  not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact. Â Gadson v. Mikasa
    Corp., 368 S.C. 214, 221, 628 S.E.2d 262, 266 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Pursuant to
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-50 (Supp. 2007), the Commission shall weigh the evidence
  as presented at the initial hearing and, if good grounds are shown, make its
  own findings of fact and reach its own conclusions of law consistent or
  inconsistent with those of the Single Commissioner.Â  Lowe v. Am-Can Transp.
    Servs. Inc., 283 S.C. 534, 537, 324 S.E.2d 87, 89 (Ct. App. 1984); see also Green v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 250 S.C. 58, 64, 156
  S.E.2d 318, 321 (1967) (holding although it is logical for the Commission to
  give weight to the Single Commissionerâ€™s opinion, the Commission may disagree
  with his findings based on the credibility of witnesses).Â  
In
  this case, the mere fact that the Commission disagreed with the Single
  Commissioner did not, by itself, constitute a failure to make an essential
  finding of fact.Â  See Lowe, 283 S.C. at 537, 324 S.E.2d at 89 (holding
  the Commission had the power to make its own findings consistent with or
  inconsistent with those of the Single Commissioner whether or not the Single Commissionerâ€™s
  holdings were based on competent substantial evidence and whether or not they
  were based on credibility of witnesses he had personally observed).Â  Rather,
  the Commissionâ€™s error was in its failure to explain its disagreement â€“ i.e.,
  its failure to explain exactly why it denied Packâ€™s claim of brain injury.Â  The
  absence of any findings to support the Commissionâ€™s denial leaves this Court no
  way of evaluating the reasoning behind the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  We,
  therefore, remand the issue to the Commission to make further findings to
  support its decision as to Packâ€™s claim of brain injury.[2]Â  See Fox, 319 S.C. at 280, 461 S.E.2d at 394 (holding when an
  administrative agency acts without first making the proper factual findings
  required by law, the proper procedure is to remand the case and allow the
  agency the opportunity to make those findings).
3. Respiratory and
Psychological Overlay
The
  Commission ruled, and the circuit court affirmed, that Pack suffered both
  respiratory and psychological injuries.Â  Appellants argue the circuit court
  erred in affirming the Commission because (a) substantial evidence does not
  support the respiratory injury claim, and (b) the psychological injury claim
  does not meet the legal standard for compensability.Â  We agree with the circuit
  court and the Commission that Packâ€™s claim of injury to her respiratory system
  is supported by substantial evidence. Â Therefore, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s
  holding as to that issue. Â However, we remand the issue of psychological injury
  to the Commission for more definite factual findings of a causal connection
  between Packâ€™s physical injuries, either brain or respiratory, and her
  psychological injuries.

  a) Respiratory Injury

Appellants
  argue the circuit court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s decision that Pack
  suffered an injury to her respiratory system because substantial evidence does
  not support a finding of a continuing respiratory injury.Â  We disagree.
â€œSubstantial
  evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly
  from one side of the case, but is evidence that, considering the record as a
  whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion as the Commission.Â  Taylor, 368 S.C. at 36, 627 S.E.2d at 752.Â  Where there are conflicts
  in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Commission are conclusive.
  Â Rogers v. Kunja Knitting Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 377, 380, 440
  S.E.2d 401, 403 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The Commission need not accept or believe
  medical or other expert testimony, even when it is unanimous, uncontroverted,
  or uncontradicted.Â  100A C.J.S. Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§1023 (2000). Â Thus, even
  sharply contradicted evidence of injury can constitute substantial evidence for
  purposes of review.Â  See, e.g., Williams v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of
    Mental Retardation, 308 S.C. 438, 439-40, 418 S.E.2d 555, 556 (Ct. App.
  1992) (holding substantial evidence supported Commissionâ€™s finding that claimant
  suffered a permanent ten percent impairment to her back, despite the fact that
  all of the experts, except claimantâ€™s family physician, agreed after close
  physical examinations that claimant had no permanent partial impairment).
While
  the evidence in the record tending to support Packâ€™s alleged respiratory injury
  is far from overwhelming,[3] the record does contain substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s
  conclusion Pack has suffered a respiratory injury.Â  Dr. Lieberman listed among
  his diagnoses â€œexcessive bronchial secretions[,] . . . wheezing[,] . . . [and]
  bronco spasms.â€Â  Dr. Stewart, a rehabilitation counselor, concluded Pack
  â€œsustained significant work-related injuries to her brain (cognitive
  dysfunction) and lungs/breathing passages.â€Â  Dr. Brian S. Dantzler, an
  allergist, diagnosed Pack with asthma â€œbased upon a combination of clinical
  history of coughing, wheezing, or episodic difficulty breathing.â€Â  Considering
  the record as a whole, this evidence could allow reasonable minds to conclude Pack
  suffered respiratory injury.Â  See Taylor, 368 S.C. at 36, 627
  S.E.2d at 752 (holding evidence is substantial if, considering the record as a
  whole, it â€œwould allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the
  administrative agency reached in order to justify its action[]â€).Â  Because the
  evidence is conflicting on this issue, the circuit court did not err in
  affirming the Commissionâ€™s holding.Â  See Rogers, 312 S.C. at 381,
  440 S.E.2d at 403 (holding the circuit courtâ€™s reversal of the Commission was
  error because although the evidence conflicted, the Commissionâ€™s findings were
  supported by substantial evidence).

  b) Psychological Injury

Appellants
  argue the circuit court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s decision that Pack
  suffered a psychological injury because Packâ€™s claim for psychological injury
  does not meet the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2007).Â 
  Although we agree with Pack that substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s
  finding that she suffered an injury to her respiratory system, we do not
  believe the Commission made adequate findings of fact establishing a causal
  connection between Packâ€™s physical injuries and her psychological injuries.Â  We,
  therefore, remand the issue to the Commission for more specific findings of a
  causal connection.
Claims
  for psychological injury are compensable only if the claimant proves by a
  preponderance of evidence they are caused by physical injury or by extraordinary
  and unusual conditions of employment.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs. Inc.,Â  357
  S.C. 520, 528, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).[4]Â 
  In this case, there is no contention Pack suffered extraordinary and unusual
  conditions of employment.Â  Therefore, for Packâ€™s psychological injuries to be
  compensable, Pack must prove a physical injury caused her psychological
  injury.Â  Estridge v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc., 325 S.C. 532, 538, 482
  S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 1997).
There
  are two alleged physical injuries in this case: brain and respiratory.Â  From
  the record, Packâ€™s position appears to be her alleged brain injury, not her
  respiratory injury, is what caused her psychological injuries.[5]Â 
  Indeed, the Single Commissioner grouped the psychological injuries with the brain
  injuries, describing Packâ€™s injuries as â€œrespiratory [and] brain with
  psychological overlay,â€ and â€œbrain accompanied with psychological overlay[]â€).Â 
  Thus, a finding that Pack has psychological injuries would seem to be
  contingent upon the Commission finding she had brain injuries.Â  It was,
  therefore, puzzling that the Commission found psychological injuries while
  denying the brain injury.Â  In doing so, the circuit court implicitly held that
  Packâ€™s respiratory injuries caused the psychological injuries.Â  However, the circuit
  court made no findings of fact to support this.
The
  task of an appellate court is to inquire whether the Commissionâ€™s findings are
  supported by substantial evidence.Â  Lark, 276 S.C. at 136, 276 S.E.2d at
  307.Â  However, without clear findings of fact, this Court cannot evaluate the
  decision of the Commission under the substantial evidence standard.Â  See Drake v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 241 S.C. 116, 123, 127 S.E.2d 288,
  292 (1962) (holding remand is proper where Commissionâ€™s order affords no
  reasonable basis upon which the appellate court can determine whether the
  findings of fact are supported by the evidence and whether the law has been
  properly applied to those findings).Â  Here, there are inadequate findings as to
  what caused Packâ€™s psychological injuries.Â  We, therefore, remand this issue to
  the Commission to make further findings as to the causal link between Packâ€™s
physical injuries, either brain or respiratory, and her psychological injuries.

CONCLUSION
As
  to the brain injury, the circuit courtâ€™s reversal of the Commission is
  reversed, and the issue is remanded to the Commission for further findings on
  brain injury.
As
  to the respiratory injury, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is affirmed.
As
  to psychological injuries, the issue is remanded to the Commission for more
  specific fact-finding on the causal link between Packâ€™s physical injuries and
  her psychological injuries.
PIEPER and
  GEATHERS, JJ., concur.

[1] Dr. Lieberman
  is a Fellow in the American Academy of Environmental Medicine and a Diplomat in
  American Board of Environmental Medicine, a member of the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine, and a member of the Carolinas Occupational
Medical Association.Â  
[2] Regardless of
  whether the Commission denies or awards brain injury on remand, this Court
simply requests that the Commission explain its reasoning thoroughly.
[3] Except for a
  few places in the record, the only context in which Packâ€™s respiratory system
  is even mentioned is in the discussion of her alleged inhalation of the
  chemical fumes that caused an injury to her brain.Â  The various evaluations in
  the record from physicians and medical professionals focus almost exclusively
  on her â€œneurocognitive dysfunction.â€Â  Few discuss her respiratory system at all.Â 
  Moreover, many (if not most) of the evaluations that do discuss her respiratory
  system suggest that it is healthy.Â  For example, Dr. Waid stated Packâ€™s
  â€œ[c]onversational speech was prosodic, fluent, or normal rate and tone.â€Â  Dr.
  Early stated â€œ[Pack] has a broad affect and laughs frequently. . . . The lungs
  are clear.â€Â  Dr. Dantzler stated Pack showed â€œno significant airflow
  obstruction in either large or small airways.â€Â  Pack even reported to one
  physician, Dr. Patrick Harm, that she is â€œactive, working out on a Bowflex
  machine three times a week, occasionally biking.â€Â  It is also worth noting that
  Pack did not even address the sufficiency of the evidence of the respiratory
injury in her brief.Â  
[4] Section
  42-1-160(B) states that mental injuries are not compensable unless the employee
establishes, by a preponderance of the evidence:
â€œ(1) that the
  employeeâ€™s employment conditions causing the stress, mental injury, or mental
  illness were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of
the particular employment; and
(2) the medical
  causation between the stress, mental injury, or mental illness, and the
stressful employment conditions by medical evidence.â€
[5] For example,
  Dr. Waid states, â€œ[s]lowed mental/cognition, difficulty sustaining
  attention/concentration, and reduced capacity for immediate learning . . . are
consistent with that expected when there is toxic injury to the brain.â€).Â

title: Skipper v. Perrone
description: Gloria N. Perrone and Carol Repec Perrone, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Joel E. Perrone appeal the order of the special referee setting aside a deed on the ground of undue influence.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Windle E.
      Skipper, as personal representative of the estate of C.D. Nixon, Respondent,
				v.
				Gloria N.
      Perrone and Carol Repec Perrone, as personal representatives of the estate of
      Joel E. Perrone, Appellants,
				v.
				Ray Nixon, LLC, Windle Skipper,
  individually and as the personal representative of the estate of C.D. Nixon,
  N.F. Nixon, Jr., and John W. Ray,Â Third-Party Defendants
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4489
Heard December 11, 2008 â€“ Filed January
  27, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Paul Dominick, of Charleston, Rose Duggan Manos, of Columbia, Willard D. Hanna, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Appellants.
				J. Jackson Thomas, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HUFF, J.:Â  Gloria N. Perrone and Carol Repec Perrone, as Personal
  Representative of the Estate of Joel E. Perrone appeal the order of the special
  referee setting aside a deed on the ground of undue influence.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL
  HISTORY
On
  October 25, 1993, a deed from C. D. Nixon to his sister, Gloria Perrone, and
  nephew, Joel E. Perrone, was filed in the Horry County Register of Deeds
  Office.Â  The deed was subsequently re-recorded on May 29, 1994. It was
  witnessed by Margaret S. Mullinax and Beverly A. Bell.Â  The stated consideration
  was $10.00.Â Â  The deed purported to convey:

	ALL AND
  SINGULAR, the properties located in the County of Horry, State of South
  Carolina, in the Little River Township now owned by the Grantor, and being the
  remaining property conveyed to the Grantor by deed of East Cherry Grove Realty
  Company, a corporation, dated June 9, 1997, and recorded in the records of
  Horry County in Deed Book 584, page 617.Â  The description in said deeds being
  included as if fully set out herein.Â  
	ALSO,
  All reservations, rights, interest in and rights of enforcing the same, which
  have not been sold, deeded, or transferred, including but not exclusiveÂ  of
  those in any roads, avenues, attests, parks, lanes or beaches, together with
  all rights which have been reserved by the Grantor in prior conveyances as
  contained in the official Cherry Grove Beach Deed as restrictions and
  conditions.Â  

Nixon passed away
  on December 13, 1995.Â  Under the terms of his will, the bulk of his estate
  passed to a corporation to be formed and owned by John W. Ray, his long time
  accountant, and Dr. N.F. Nixon, Jr., his nephew and personal physician.Â 
  Neither Gloria nor Joel Perrone was a beneficiary under the will.[1]Â  
Windle E. Skipper,
  the personal representative of Nixonâ€™s estate, brought the present action on
  October 1, 2003 seeking to have the deed set aside on the grounds of lack of
  consideration, undue influence, lack of competency, that the deed was executed
  in blank, and lack of required witnesses.Â  The circuit court dismissed the
  grounds of lack of consideration and lack of required witnesses.Â  The remaining
  grounds were tried before the special referee.Â Â  
The special referee
  found that during the latter part of 1993 Nixon was either incompetent or
  substantially impaired due to his advanced age and physical and mental
  condition.Â  In addition, the referee held the consideration for the deed was
  grossly inadequate.Â  Accordingly, the referee concluded the deed should be set
  aside on the grounds of undue influence.Â  He rejected Appellantsâ€™ defenses of laches, estoppel, and waiver. Â Appellants filed a motion to reconsider, alter,
  or amend, which the referee denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  action to set aside a deed on the basis of undue influence is an action in
  equity.Â  Donnan v. Mariner, 339 S.C. 621, 626, 529 S.E.2d 754, 757 (Ct.
  App. 2000).Â  When reviewing an action in equity, this court may review the
  evidence to determine facts in accordance with our own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301
  S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  â€œWhile this permits us a broad
  scope of review, we do not disregard the findings of the [referee], who saw and
  heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their
  credibility.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Undue influence
Appellants
  argue the referee erred in finding the deed was the product of undue
  influence.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally,
  the party attacking a deed has the burden of proof.Â  Middleton v. Suber,
  300 S.C. 402, 405, 388 S.E.2d 639, 641 (1990).Â  However, the supreme court held
  an inference of undue influence will arise upon a showing of great mental
  weakness of the grantor and gross inadequacy of consideration.Â  Brooks v.
    Kay, 339 S.C. 479, 490, 530 S.E.2d 120, 125-26 (2000).Â  The court
  explained:

	It is
  not necessary, in order to secure the aid of equity, to prove that the deceased
  (grantor) was at the time insane, or in such a state of mental imbecility as to
  render her entirely incapable of executing a valid deed. It is sufficient to
  show that from her sickness and infirmities she was at the time in a condition
  of great mental weakness, and that there was gross inadequacy of consideration
  for the conveyance. From these circumstances imposition of undue influence will
  be inferred.

Id. at 490, 530 S.E.2d at 125-26.Â  The court recognized
  this inference applies even absent a confidential relationship.Â  Id. at 490, 530 S.E.2d at 126.
The
  referee held that Nixon was either incompetent or substantially impaired due to
  his advanced age and physical and mental condition at the time of the execution
  of the deed.Â  Dr. N.F. Nixon, who was Nixonâ€™s nephew, treating physician, and
  one of the remainder beneficiaries of his estate, testified that in late 1990
  or early 1991, Gloria Perroneâ€™s daughter, Melinda Floyd, spoke to him about her
  concerns that the people who were supposed to be looking after Nixon were in
  fact looking out for their own interests and were getting him to sign deeds.Â 
  On July 10, 1991, Gloria Perrone, Â Floyd, and Dr. Nixon met with the probate
  judge.Â  However, at that time they were not ready to have Nixon declared
  incompetent and no action was taken.Â  
Dr.
  Nixon stated that by the early 1990â€™s, Nixon had undergone senile dementia and
  was not capable of protecting himself from people who were taking advantage of
  him.Â  He described Nixonâ€™s living conditions as squalid and stated Nixon was
  always on the couch reeking of urine and was unable to toilet himself.Â  Dr.
  Nixon asserted Nixon would â€œsign just about anything that anyone would bring to
  him, just to get away from the stress of it.â€Â  Dr. Nixon related that in 1992,
  he had Nixon grant him a deed to a tract adjoining property he already owned.Â 
  Dr. Nixon acknowledged that although he believed C.D. Nixon knew him and agreed
  to the sign the deed, he did not have the ability to not sign and that Nixon
  would sign anything anyone brought him.Â  
Margaret
  Mullinax, who lived with Nixon from August of 1993 until his death, testified
  that when she came to live with him, his entire house smelled of urine and he
  had not been well taken care of by his previous caretaker.Â  She and other
  family members decided to have the county nurses come to Nixonâ€™s house to check
  on him regularly. Â She stated the previous caretaker took advantage of Nixon
  and had him sign deeds giving her property.Â  She recalled Nixon often signed
  deeds in blank and left them lying around.Â Â Â Â  
Carlton
  Bell, Nixonâ€™s longtime attorney, stated that after Nixon broke his arm in 1991
  or 1992, his dementia progressed.Â  On December 16, 1993, when Nixon came to Bellâ€™s office to execute a deed, Bell had great concerns about Nixonâ€™s competency to
  execute the deed.Â  Bell allowed Nixon to execute the deed because he believed
  that if Nixon had not executed the deed, he and Nixonâ€™s other attorney in fact
  could have executed it on his behalf.[2]Â  He stated he did not
  want to have to tell Nixon he was incompetent when the transaction would have
  happened anyway.Â Â  That was the last deed Bell helped Nixon execute. 
Not
  long after Nixon executed the deed in the present case, he executed a deed on
  November 17, 1993 reserving a life estate to himself in all of his property in Horry County and conveying the remainder to Gloria Perroneâ€™s daughters Debbie Perrone
  Fowler and Melinda Perrone Fowler, a great niece Sue Nye Watson, and Margaret Mullinax.Â 
  This deed was subsequently set aside on the basis of undue influence.Â  Although
  Bell executed several deeds during this time period that have not been set aside,
  there is no evidence Skipper or Bell himself sought to set aside those deeds.Â  
In
  May or June of 1994, Bell visited Nixon after receiving a call from his
  caretaker, Olea Ward.Â  Bell found Nixon in an almost comatose state.Â  Bell
  called Dr. Nixon and another friend of Nixon to help them. Â In September of
  1994, Dr. Nixon, Gloria Perrone and other family members filed a petition for a
  conservator for Nixon.Â  The probate court appointed temporary joint conservators
  in October of 1994. 
We
  agree with the referee that Bell was in substantially weakened mental state at
  the time of the execution of the deed. 
In
  addition, the referee held the compensation listed in the deed was grossly
  inadequate.Â  There is no evidence in the record as to the exact value of the
  property.Â  However, Bell testified the deed conveyed the marsh and whatever
  else the East Cherry Grove Realty Company may have owned at the time of its
  dissolution.Â  This included a channel lot, which Bell stated was extremely
  valuable at the time of the execution of the deed.[3]Â 
  Â In addition, the property conveyed by the deed included land between the front
  line of lots previously conveyed and the Atlantic Ocean.Â  Bell explained that
  the mean high water mark had changed since the original deeds leaving up to 300
  feet between the lots.Â  Nixon had seen the property as having some value and
  had contacted lot owners inquiring if they wanted to expand their lots and most
  of them did at some price.Â  Bell testified that according to the State of South
  Carolina, the marshland was worth approximately eight hundred to a million
  dollars per acre.Â  It would also be worth something to an adjoining landowner
  who needed access to the channel across the property.Â  However, to someone who
  does not own property there, it has no value.Â  
After
  receiving the deed, the Perrones brought several actions against DHEC, the City
  of North Myrtle Beach, and private parties asserting their exclusive rights to
  the properties and seeking damages.Â  In an order approving plans for pursuing
  real property claims by the estate of Joel Perrone, the probate court noted the
  Perronesâ€™ attorney informed the court that the claims â€œcould amount to millions
  of dollars in recoveries.â€Â  Thus the evidence in the record is that the
  property was extremely valuable and potentially worth millions.Â  We find the
  evidence supports the refereeâ€™s determination that the consideration for the
  deed of $10.00 was grossly inadequate.Â  Accordingly, we hold the referee did
  not err in inferring the deed was the product of undue influence.Â Â Â Â  
2.  Laches
The
  Perrones argue the referee erred in failing to apply the doctrine of laches to
  bar Skipperâ€™s claims.Â  We disagree. 
â€œUnder
  the doctrine of laches, if a party, knowing his rights, does not seasonably
  assert them, but by unreasonable delay causes his adversary to incur expenses
  or enter into obligations or otherwise detrimentally change his position, then
  equity will ordinarily refuse to enforce those rights.â€ Chambers of S. C.,
    Inc. v. County Council for Lee County, 315 S.C. 418, 421, 434 S.E.2d 279,
  280 (1993). Â â€œLaches connotes not only an undue lapse of time, but also
  negligence and opportunity to have acted sooner.â€ Â Id. at 421, 434 at
  281. The party seeking to establish laches must show (1) delay, (2)
  unreasonable delay, and (3) prejudice. Â Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C.
  195, 199, 371 S.E.2d 525, 528 (1988).
The
  Perrones assert the doctrine of laches should apply because this action was not
  filed until almost ten years after the date of the deed.Â  They assert they were
  prejudiced by the delay because by the date of the trial, Joel Perrone had
  passed away, and Gloria Perrone was in such poor health that she could not testify
  at trial.Â  In addition, deed witness Beverly Bell was unable to testify at
  trial because of her health problems, Olea Ward passed away before the trial,
  and Margaret Mullinax could not be located to testify at trial.Â  
From the time Nixon
  executed the deed until his death, he suffered from diminished mental capacity
  and may not have been able to bring an action to set aside the deed.Â  Skipper
  testified that he was not familiar with the deed before Nixon died and after
  Nixonâ€™s death he concentrated on having another deed set aside.Â  He stated he
  did not really concentrate on the present deed until he was about to close the
  estate and it was brought to his attention that he should look at the deed.Â  By
  then, Joel Perrone had passed away and Gloria Perrone was bedridden. We find
  Skipper did not exercise unreasonable delay in bringing this action once he was
  aware of the circumstances of the deed.Â  In addition, the prejudice to the
  Perrones was not as great as they claim.Â Â  Although Ward, Mullinax, and Beverly
  Bell were not able to testify at trial, they had previously testified in
  depositions, which were presented at trial.Â Â Â  
The referee held,
  â€œI see nothing in the facts of the case at bar to indicate that here, where
  undue influence was used to obtain valuable property from an old, sick,
  mentally weak man, the Court should exercise its discretion in favor of [the Perronesâ€™] laches defense.â€Â  This court recognized, â€œLaches is a defense in
  equity, and one who comes to the court seeking equity must come with clean
  hands.â€ Â Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 220, 603 S.E.2d 598, 605 (Ct.
  App. 2004).
Accordingly, we
  find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling on this issue.Â  
3.  Waiver
The
  Perrones argue the referee erred in failing to apply the doctrine of waiver to
  bar Skipperâ€™s claim.Â  They assert that Nixon intentionally abandoned and waived
  a claim to set aside the deed by taking no action after telling Bell that he
  wanted to have the deed set aside.Â  We disagree.
Waiver
  is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment of a known right.Â  Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 85, 650 S.E.2d 465, 470 (2007).Â 
  It may be expressed or implied by a partyâ€™s conduct.Â  Parker v. Parker,
  313 S.C. 482, 487, 443 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1994).
At
  the time Nixon discussed setting aside the deed with Bell, he was greatly
  infirmed.Â  Bell, who was his long-time attorney, advised him that he would have
  to seek another attorney to represent him as Bell would most likely have to
  appear as a witness in an action to set aside the deed.Â  We find Nixon did not
  intentionally abandon the claim by not trying to find another attorney, given
  his mental condition.
CONCLUSION
For the
  foregoing reasons, the decision of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  HUFF, and THOMAS, JJ. concur.Â  



[1] Nixon left an unwitnessed memorandum to his will
  dated September 27, 1993 which provided:

	Recent
  events and statements made by several of my family members wherein they
  indicated that they might contest my Will or bring other actions against my
  Estate or Personal Representatives prompts me to issue this memorandum and ask
  that any court deny and reject such claims and that they receive no share of my
  Estate.

[2] Unknown to Bell, the power of attorney naming Bell and Olea Ward as attorneys in fact was revoked on October 27, 1993.Â  
[3] Bell had handled transactions for similar lots and
  was familiar with their value.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				David J. Widener, Appellant,
				v.
				Fort Mill Ford, and WFS Financial,Â Defendants,
				of whom:
				Fort Mill Ford is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Master In Equity
Opinion No. 4490
Heard December 3, 2008 â€“ Filed January 27,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Mitchell K. Byrd, Sr., of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				Ronald J. Tryon and J. Drayton Hastie,
  III, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, A.J.: David J. Widener brought this action against Fort
  Mill Ford and WFS Financial (WFS) alleging violations of the South Carolina
  Regulation of Manufacturers, Distributors, and Dealers Act, sections 56-15-10
  to -600 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) (the Dealers Act), and the
  Unfair Trade Practices Act, sections 39-5-10 to -560 of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2007).Â  In response, Fort Mill Ford moved to dismiss or stay the
  proceedings and to compel arbitration.Â  After a hearing, the trial court
  dismissed the action, holding â€œ[t]he arbitration agreement is enforceable by
  [Fort Mill Ford and WFS] pursuant to the Federal Arbitration Act as to the
  claims asserted by [Widener] in this litigation.â€Â  Widener appeals.Â  We reverse
  and remand. 
I.  APPEALABILITY
Widener argues the trial courtâ€™s order dismissing his
  action is immediately appealable.Â  Fort Mill Ford contends the trial courtâ€™s
  order is not appealable, citing section 15-48-200 of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2007) and Carolina Care Plan, Inc. v. United HealthCare Services,
    Inc., 361 S.C. 544, 558, 606 S.E.2d 752, 759 (2004).
South Carolina courts
  have not specifically addressed the issue of whether an order dismissing an
  action without prejudice and allowing the parties to pursue arbitration is
  immediately appealable.Â  The United States Supreme Court addressed a similar
  issue in Green Tree Financial Corp.-Alabama v. Randolph, 531 U.S. 79
  (2000).Â  The court held an order dismissing an action with prejudice and directing
  that the dispute be resolved by arbitration is final and immediately
  appealable.Â  Id. at 86-87.Â  The court added, â€œHad the District Court
  entered a stay instead of a dismissal in this case, that order would not be
  appealable.â€Â  Id. at 87 n.2.Â  Further, both the Second Circuit and the
  Ninth Circuit have held that orders dismissing actions without prejudice and
  compelling arbitration are immediately appealable.Â  See Salim
    Oleochemicals v. M/V Shropshire, 278 F.3d 90, 93 (2d Cir. 2002); Interactive
      Flight Techs., Inc. v. Swissair Swiss Air Transport Co., Ltd., 249 F.3d
  1177, 1179 (9th Cir. 2001).
We therefore hold the trial courtâ€™s order is
  immediately appealable.Â  
Fort Mill Fordâ€™s reliance on section 15-48-200 is misplaced.Â 
  Although section 15-48-200 does not include an order dismissing an action among
  a list of orders from which an appeal may be taken in arbitration cases, this
  section does not preclude the order in this case from being immediately
  appealable.Â  By dismissing Widenerâ€™s action, the court finally determined the
  rights of the parties; therefore, we have jurisdiction pursuant to section
  14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).Â  
Further, this case is distinguishable from Carolina
  Care Plan.Â  In Carolina Care Plan, our supreme court held an order
  compelling arbitration and staying the remaining claims is not immediately
  appealable.Â  361 S.C. at 558, 606 S.E.2d at 759.  Here, however, the trial
  courtâ€™s order did not stay the action pending arbitration.Â  Instead, trial
  court dismissed the action, stating, â€œIt is further ordered that this
  action be dismissed without prejudice to the right of any party to seek such
  relief as may be available to enforce, modify, or vacate any arbitration
  decision as permitted by statute.â€ 
II.  DISMISSALÂ 
  Â Â Â Â 
Widener argues the trial court erred in dismissing his
  action.Â  He asserts the dismissal prejudices him because any future action will
  be barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We agree.
Although South Carolina courts have not addressed this
  issue, the Alabama Supreme Court dealt with a similar situation in Johnson
    v. Jefferson County Racing Assâ€™n, 2008 WL 2554013, 7 (Ala. 2008).Â  The Johnson court pointed to the following discussion, which appears in Porter v.
      Colonial Life & Accident Insurance Co., 828 So. 2d 907, 908 (Ala. 2002):

	â€œWe note a potential for injustice. If a plaintiffâ€™s
  court action be dismissed to enforce an arbitration agreement, but, through no
  fault of the plaintiffâ€™s, the arbitration be not concluded or some of the
  plaintiffâ€™s claims be not arbitrated, a statute of limitations could bar a
  refiling of the unarbitrated claims in court.Â  Sometimes, for instance, an
  arbitratorâ€™s first duty under an arbitration agreement is to determine the
  arbitrability of a plaintiffâ€™s claims. In such a case, the arbitrator could
  rule that some or all of the plaintiffâ€™s claims should be litigated and not
  arbitrated. Moreover, a stay, as distinguished from a dismissal, would likely
  better conserve the time and resources of the parties and the trial court even
  in the event of a successful arbitration, inasmuch as the winner commonly wants
  the arbitration award reduced to a judgment.â€ 

Here, as in Johnson, there is a potential the
  statute of limitations could bar refiling of any unarbitrated claims in court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 39-5-150 & 56-15-120 (Supp. 2007).Â  
Accordingly, we reverse the decision of the trial
  court and remand this case for the trial court to vacate its dismissal of
  Widenerâ€™s claims and to enter an order staying his action pending the outcome
  of the arbitration proceedings.
III.  ARBITRATION
Widener argues the trial court erred in concluding his
  causes of action are subject to arbitration.Â  We do not reach this issue
  because we are reversing and remanding this case for the trial court to stay
  this action pending arbitration.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.

title: Payne v. Payne
description: Sherry Ann Payne (Mother) appeals from a family court order transferring custody of her minor son, Joshua Michael Payne, to William John Payne (Father).  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				William John Payne, Respondent,

				Sherry Payne, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4491
Heard November 6, 2008 â€“ Filed January 27,
  2009Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Douglas Kosta Kotti, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Pamela Michele Pearson, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Sherry Ann Payne (Mother) appeals from a family court
  order transferring custody of her minor son, Joshua Michael Payne, to William
  John Payne (Father).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Mother
  and Father separated in 1996 after four years of marriage; however, they did
  not divorce until 2001.Â  The coupleâ€™s son, Joshua, was one year old at the
  time.Â  During the separation and following the divorce proceedings, Mother was
  awarded primary custody of Joshua.Â  Father was given supervised visitation
  until Joshuaâ€™s sixth birthday, at which point Father began a two-year gradual
  introduction to â€œstandard [unsupervised] visitation.â€Â  This phased-in custody
  arrangement was the result of Fatherâ€™s status as a convicted sex offender, per
  a 1989 Criminal Sexual Conduct (CSC) conviction, and Motherâ€™s allegations of
  domestic violence by Father directed toward herself and Joshua during the
  separation and pendency of the divorce proceedings.Â  Father remarried later in
  2001, and ultimately began having unsupervised visitation.Â  
In October of 2004, both parents were named as
  defendants in a South Carolina Department of Social Services action stemming
  from allegations made by Joshuaâ€™s pediatrician, Dr. Deanna Threatt.Â  Threatt
  expressed concern that Joshuaâ€™s frequent hospitalization and illnesses may be a
  form of child abuse, and after consulting with other doctors in her practice
  group, diagnosed Mother with Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy.Â  DSS was notified
  and the police were called.Â  At the probable cause hearing, temporary custody
  was initially given to maternal grandmother.Â  Following DSS in-home evaluations
  of both Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s homes, temporary custody was awarded to Father
  for the pendency of the DSS case.Â  Ultimately, the court found Joshua was not
  abused and returned custody to Mother.Â  
In
  2005, Father filed an action seeking modification of the family courtâ€™s custody
  order in light of the DSS incident.Â  In her answer and counterclaim, Mother
  requested that:Â  (1) Fatherâ€™s visitation be reduced to supervised or restricted
  visits; (2) the action be dismissed; (3) the parties be permitted to engage in
  discovery; and (4) Father pay her attorney fees and costs.Â  
Following
  a trial, the family court issued a final order that, in relevant part,
  transferred custody of Joshua to Father as well as set a visitation schedule
  for Mother.Â  At the same time, Motherâ€™s counsel withdrew his representation.Â Â Â  
Shortly thereafter, Motherâ€™s new attorney filed a
  â€œmotion to reconsider with exceptions,â€ which was denied.Â  Because no one had
  notified the clerk of courtâ€™s office that Motherâ€™s previous attorney no longer
  represented her, neither Mother, nor her new attorney, received the written
  order until January 29, 2007.Â Mother filed a pro se notice of
  appeal on February 26, 2007.Â  
On March 14, 2007 Fatherâ€™s attorney moved to dismiss
  the appeal as untimely.Â  Following Fatherâ€™s motion, both Motherâ€™s former
  attorney and Motherâ€™s attorney for the post-trial motion petitioned this court
  to be relieved as counsel of record for Mother.Â  Mother consented to the
  motions, and on the same day, Motherâ€™s current attorney filed a notice of representation.Â 
  Fatherâ€™s motion to dismiss the appeal was denied, but the parties were directed
  to address the issue of timeliness in their briefs.Â  Â Â Â 
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family
  court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi,
  364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v.
    Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  However,
  this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s
  findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct.
  App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Neither is the appellate court required to ignore the fact
  that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32,
  34 (2004); Holler v. Holler, 364 S.C. 256, 261, 612 S.E.2d 469,
  472 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Because the family court is in a superior position
  to judge the witness demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad
  discretion.Â  Durlach v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 70, 596 S.E.2d 908,
  912 (2004); Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206, 211-12, 634 S.E.2d 51, 54
  (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  The Modification Order
â€œ[W]hen a non-custodial parent seeks a change in
  custody, the non-custodial parent must establish the following: (1) there has
  been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child
  and (2) a change in custody is in the overall best interests of the child.â€Â  Latimer
    v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 381, 602 S.E.2d 32, 35 (2004).Â  At trial, Father
  successfully argued both prongs of Latimer and asks this court to affirm
  the family courtâ€™s ruling.
On appeal, Mother argues the family court erred in
  granting Fatherâ€™s request for modification of the custody order for the
  following reasons:Â  (1) failure to properly consider Fatherâ€™s status as a
  convicted sex offender; (2) failure to properly apply the doctrine of issue
  preclusion; (3) failure to comply with the childâ€™s preference regarding
  custody; and (4) failure to comply with the Private Guardian Ad Litem Reform
  Act barring the guardian from making a custody recommendation unless requested
  by the court for reasons specified in the record.Â  She also asserts the family
  court erred in requiring her to pay one-half of the GAL fees.Â  We disagree and
  affirm. 
A.  Fatherâ€™s Status as a Convicted
  Sex Offender
Mother argues the family court erred by failing to
  give adequate consideration to Fatherâ€™s sex offender status.Â  Mother points to
  section 20-7-1530(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) as requiring the
  family court to consider Fatherâ€™s sex offender status with respect to custody.Â 
  While Mother is correct insofar as Â§ 20-7-1530(A) requires the court to give
  weight to â€œsexual abuseâ€ in determining the best interest of the child, other
  relevant factors must also be considered.Â  See Pountain v. Pountain,
  332 S.C. 130, 136, 503 S.E.2d 757, 760 (Ct. App. 1998) (stating that when
  determining the best interests of the child, the family court should consider
  how the custody decision will impact all areas of the childâ€™s life, including physical,
  psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional, and recreational
  aspects).Â  
Here,
  the family court was well aware of Fatherâ€™s sex offender status but simply
  declined to give it the weight desired by Mother.Â  On direct examination,
  Father was questioned by his counsel regarding the circumstances of his CSC
  conviction.Â  Father testified concerning the counseling and other remedial
  measures required of him as a result of his CSC conviction.Â  During Fatherâ€™s
  cross examination on this issue, the family court stated, â€œI want to know the
  relevance of this . . . theyâ€™ve been in court many, many times and I know
  thatâ€™s a fact; Iâ€™ve got all this in evidence, and . . . I just donâ€™t think
  thatâ€™s very relevant to this case.â€Â  Thus, there is no question the family
  court judge was aware of Fatherâ€™s 1989 CSC conviction.Â Â Â  
The family court based its custody decision primarily
  upon Motherâ€™s emotional and physical abuse of Joshua as testified to by Dr.
  Threatt, including, â€œnumerous unnecessary [medical] procedures and
  hospitalizations.â€Â  The court also relied on the testimony of Dr. Robert
  Noelker, who, in addition to expressing concerns over Motherâ€™s serious
  personality disorder and its effect on Motherâ€™s ability to parent, believed
  Father would provide Joshua a better home environment.Â  Dr. Noelker also noted
  that due to the nature of Motherâ€™s personality disorder, extensive, long-term
  treatment, including the use of psychotropic medications, would be required to
  effectively treat her.Â  Noelker additionally found Father was, â€œan excellent
  role model,â€ and there were no current issues which would affect his ability to
  parent.Â Â  
The Guardian ad Litem (GAL), Dr. Jane Rankin, echoed
  Noelkerâ€™s statements regarding custody and testified Father was an involved
  parent who spent much time with Joshua.Â  Rankin found Joshua to be â€œmore
  relaxedâ€ and â€œmore independentâ€ while in Fatherâ€™s custody during the DSS
  action.Â  Additionally, Rankin reported Joshua was â€œtenseâ€ and â€œshyâ€ upon
  returning to Motherâ€™s custody following termination of the DSS action. 
The family courtâ€™s custody decision was further
  supported by Joshuaâ€™s principal, who testified Joshua missed approximately
  thirty days of school from the beginning of school until late October, while in
  Motherâ€™s custody, and only one day of school after custody was transferred to
  Father during the DSS action.Â  She further noted that Joshua seemed â€œmore
  relaxed and outgoingâ€ when Father had primary custody.
B.  Issue Preclusion/ Collateral Estoppel
Mother also argues Fatherâ€™s custody modification
  action was precluded by the ruling in the prior DSS case, and therefore,
  maintains the family court erred in not dismissing the action.Â  We disagree.
According to our supreme court, issue preclusion, also
  known as collateral estoppel, occurs when the party in a second action is
  precluded from re-litigating an issue which was decided in a previous action.Â  Zurcher
    v. Bilton, 379 S.C. 132, 135-36, 666 S.E.2d 224, 226 (2008) (stating an issue litigated and determined by a valid and final
  judgment is conclusive in a subsequent action whether on the same or a
  different claim).Â  In order to successfully
  assert issue preclusion, a party must show the issue was actually litigated and
  directly determined in the prior action, and that the matter or fact directly
  in issue was necessary to support the first judgment.Â  Plott v.
    Justin Enters., 374 S.C. 504, 513, 649 S.E.2d 92, 96 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (citing Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 318 S.C. 340, 344, 457
  S.E.2d 626, 628 (1995)).
Mother mischaracterizes the issue before the family
  court in the DSS action as a custody action.Â  While it is true that custody was
  transferred to Father during the pendency of the DSS hearings, the issue in the
  DSS action was whether Mother abused or neglected Joshua.Â  By comparison, the
  issue before the family court in the custody modification action was whether a
  substantial change affecting the welfare of the child had occurred and whether
  a change in custody would serve the best interests of the child.Â  As the issue
  of custody between Mother and Father was neither litigated nor directly
  determined in the DSS action, we affirm as to this issue.Â  
C.Â  Consideration of Joshuaâ€™s
  Preference Regarding Custody
Mother further argues Joshuaâ€™s preference was not
  given sufficient weight by the family court.Â  We disagree.
When determining issues of custody, â€œthe court should
  consider all the circumstances of the particular case and all relevant factors
  must be taken into consideration.â€Â  Pirayesh v. Pirayesh, 359 S.C. 284,
  296, 596 S.E.2d 505, 512 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  While the childâ€™s reasonable
  preference is a factor in considering the best interest of the child, it is not
  controlling.Â  Brown v. Brown, 362 S.C. 85, 96, 606 S.E.2d 785, 791 (Ct.
  App. 2004). Â Additionally, the trial court is required to, â€œplace weight upon
  the preference based upon the childâ€™s age, experience, maturity, judgment, and
  ability to express a preference.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1515 (Supp. 2007).Â  
While
  not expressing an outright preference, Joshua stated that â€œhe wanted things to
  stay the way they were.â€Â  The family court acknowledged Joshuaâ€™s preference in
  the final order, but clearly took other factors, such as Motherâ€™s emotional
  condition and its impact upon Joshua, into consideration in its decision to
  modify the custody arrangement.Â  Accordingly, we do not believe the family
  court erred in failing to give Joshuaâ€™s preference controlling weight.
D.Â  The Private Guardian Ad Litem
  Reform Act
Mother next asserts the family court erred by failing
  to set forth in the record the specific grounds for requesting the GALâ€™s
  custody recommendation, as required by the Private Guardian Ad Litem Reform
  Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549(6) (Supp. 2007).Â 
  Mother argues that, as a result of failing to give reasons for accepting the
  GAL custody recommendation, the GAL usurped the trial courtâ€™s role as a
  decision maker.Â  Here, Mother did not object when the GAL gave her
  recommendation; therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â 
  To be preserved for appellate review, an issue must have been raised to and
  ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  Issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial
  court will not be considered on appeal.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp. v. First
    Carolina Corp. of S.C., 372 S.C. 295, 301-02, 641 S.E.2d 903, 907 (2007).Â Â  
II.  The GAL Fees
Finally, Mother argues the family court erred in its
  division of the GAL fees.Â  Additionally, Mother argues, â€œthere is no recorded
  order appointing the [GAL] and no recorded order setting her fee rate or an
  initial authorization of her fees.â€Â  We disagree.
South Carolina law provides that the family court should review the
  following factors when awarding GAL fees:

	(1) the complexity of the issues before
  the court; (2) the contentiousness of the litigation; (3) the time expended by
  the guardian; (4) the expenses reasonably incurred by the guardian; (5) the
  financial ability of each party to pay fees and costs; and (6) any other
  factors the court considers necessary.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1553(B) (Supp. 2007).
â€œAn award of GAL fees lies within the
  sound discretion of the [family court] and will not be disturbed on appeal
  absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 341,
  536 S.E.2d 427, 436 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The trial court abuses its discretion
  when a decision is based upon an error of law or upon factual findings that are
  without evidentiary support.Â  State v. Morris, 376 S.C. 189, 206, 656
  S.E.2d 359, 368 (2008).Â  
After reviewing the GALâ€™s time expenditure
  and her hourly rate, the family court found the GAL competently
  performed her services and was entitled to payment of her fees and expenses in
  the amount of $3,773.Â  This was consistent with a July 29, 2005, order that
  appointed Dr. Rankin, set her hourly rate, and determined that each party would
  share equal responsibility for the balance of the fees owed to the guardian.Â 
  Consequently, the family court did not abuse its discretion by splitting the
  guardian fees between the parties. 
The ruling of the family court is
  accordingly 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.

title: State v. Parker
description: In October of 2003, Parker stood trial for murder before Judge Hayes.  The jury twice reported to Judge Hayes its inability to reach a unanimous verdict.  Judge Hayes granted Parkerâ€™s motion for a mistrial.  When Parker was tried again in 2005 before Judge Few, he moved to dismiss based on double jeopardy.  Judge Few denied the motion and the jury convicted Parker of murder.  Parker appeals his murder conviction arguing Judge Few erred in denying his motion to dismiss based on double jeopardy.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Jack Edward
          Earl Parker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4492
  Heard November 6, 2008 â€“ Filed January 28,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,
          and Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and
          Solicitor Robert Mills Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â 
  In October of 2003, Parker stood trial for murder before Judge Hayes.Â  The jury
  twice reported to Judge Hayes its inability to reach a unanimous verdict.Â 
  Judge Hayes granted Parkerâ€™s motion for a mistrial.Â  When Parker was tried
  again in 2005 before Judge Few, he moved to dismiss based on double jeopardy.Â 
  Judge Few denied the motion and the jury convicted Parker of murder.Â  Parker
  appeals his murder conviction arguing Judge Few erred in denying his motion to
  dismiss based on double jeopardy.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Parker shot and killed Robert Lee Stewart.Â  Stewart had an
  extensive violent criminal background and a history of abusive behavior toward
  Parkerâ€™s sister, Angela.Â  The police and emergency medical technicians
  responded to a call to Angelaâ€™s motherâ€™s house after Angela was beaten by
  Stewart.Â  The following day, Stewart and four or five others arrived at
  Angelaâ€™s motherâ€™s house.Â  Parker lived next door to Angelaâ€™s mother.Â  Parker
  shot Stewart multiple times in the driveway.Â  At trial, Parker claimed
  self-defense, testifying he feared for his life as Stewart was pulling
  something from his back pocket and from the back of the truck.Â  Police officer
  Wayne Campbell testified an open knife was found in the victimâ€™s back pocket at
  the scene.Â  
During the first trial, there was a significant amount of
  animosity between the solicitor and defense counsel, appearing in the record as
  early as pre-trial motions and continuing throughout the proceedings.Â  Prior to
  questioning the first police witness, the solicitor explained to the court that
  there was a videotape made of the crime scene that included graphic footage of
  the victimâ€™s body.Â  The solicitor redacted that footage and presented defense
  counsel with the redacted copy on the day of trial.Â  The original videotape,
  however, was shown to the jury.Â  The solicitor claimed it was unintentional.Â 
  Defense counsel moved for a mistrial and dismissal with prejudice based on
  prosecutorial misconduct.Â  He argued the solicitorâ€™s case was not going well
  and the State was now privy to his defense tactics.Â  The solicitor argued she
  did not know how the tapes were switched and there was no intention on her part
  to force a mistrial.Â  The court admonished the solicitor, but denied the motion
  for a mistrial.Â  
At the end of the Stateâ€™s case, Parker moved for a directed
  verdict.Â  The court denied the motion finding that although the Stateâ€™s case
  had many lapses in evidence, there was sufficient evidence to present the case
  to the jury.Â  Parker testified he acted in self-defense.Â  The trial court
  denied Parkerâ€™s renewed motions for directed verdict and mistrial.Â  The court
  also prohibited the State from sending the videotape and a diagram of the body
  depicting the victimâ€™s wounds to the jury room. 
After the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, Parker again moved for a
  mistrial.Â  The court charged the jury and then heard arguments on the motion.Â 
  Parkerâ€™s counsel argued that many times during the trial, the solicitor accused
  him of unethical conduct, badgered witnesses to concede they were merely
  testifying as directed to by Parkerâ€™s counsel, and stated several times in
  closing arguments that Parkerâ€™s counsel had coached the defense witnesses.Â  He
  further argued the solicitor improperly relied on numerous facts that were not
  in the record and implied to the jury it was their community duty to convict
  Parker of murder.Â  He finally argued the cumulative effect of the prosecutorial
  misconduct warranted a mistrial.Â  
Prior to a ruling on the motion, the jury reported to the judge it
  was deadlocked.Â  The judge gave an Allen charge.Â  After further
  deliberation, the jury again reported it was deadlocked.Â  The judge considered
  the motion for a mistrial.Â  The judge stated he had reviewed the motion for a
  mistrial, the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, and his notes from the testimony.Â 
  The judge found the solicitorâ€™s comments during closing argument were improper,
  constituted prosecutorial misconduct, and were alone sufficient to warrant a
  mistrial.Â  The judge also found the attacks on Parkerâ€™s counsel, the imposition
  of the burden on the jury to convict in order to protect the community, and the
  videotape warranted a mistrial.Â  The court stated:Â  â€œIn my readings of those
  opinions itâ€™s almost as if . . . this court can infer that the defendant was
  almost goaded into the position of asking for the mistrial.Â  So based on the
  totality of the circumstances that [have] occurred in this trial . . . I will
  declare a mistrial.â€
The court ultimately based the mistrial on the cumulative effects
  of the misconduct.Â  The State moved for a clarification of Judge Hayesâ€™ order,
  requesting a finding as to whether the mistrial was granted based on
  prosecutorial misconduct that was intended to: â€œ(a) subvert the protections
  afforded by the Double Jeopardy Clause, (b) goad or provoke the defense into
  moving for a mistrial or (c) terminate the trial.â€Â  By letter, Judge Hayes
  responded he had reviewed the transcript and his notes and concluded:Â  â€œNowhere
  do I find that this Court was ever asked to rule on the granting of a new trial
  nor asked about the issue of jeopardy.â€Â  The State appealed and this court
  dismissed it as not immediately appealable.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The
  State tried Parker again. Â Parker moved to dismiss based on double
  jeopardy arguing the solicitor at the first trial intentionally goaded him into
  moving for a mistrial.Â  Judge Few denied the motion to dismiss stating: Â â€œ[R]egardless
  of my analysis of what happened in the first trial, this motion to dismiss is
  denied because it was the juryâ€™s being deadlocked that [led] to the manifest
  necessity that [led] to the mistrial.â€Â  Judge Few then stated he had analyzed
  the case and reviewed the transcript.Â  Judge Few concluded the solicitor had
  not intentionally goaded the defense into moving for a mistrial.Â  The second
  trial proceeded and the jury convicted Parker of murder.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Parker argues the trial court in the second trial
  erred in denying his motion to dismiss based on double jeopardy.Â  Parker argues
  the solicitorâ€™s conduct, including showing the jury the videotape of the
  victimâ€™s body and implying the defense counsel coached the witnesses during her
  closing arguments, was intended to goad him into moving for a mistrial.Â  We
  find no reversible error.
The
  Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions
  protect citizens from being twice placed in jeopardy of life or liberty.Â  See U.S. Const. amend. V (â€œNo person shall be . . . subject for the same offen[s]e
  to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb . . . .â€); S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 12
  (â€œNo person shall be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy
  of life or liberty . . . .â€).Â  â€œUnder the law of double jeopardy, a defendant
  may not be prosecuted for the same offense after an acquittal, a conviction, or
  an improvidently granted mistrial.â€Â  State v. Coleman, 365 S.C. 258,
  262-63, 616 S.E.2d 444, 446-47 (Ct. App. 2005).
A
  defendant who has moved for and been granted a mistrial based on prosecutorial
  misconduct may successfully invoke the Double Jeopardy Clause to prevent a
  second prosecution when the prosecutorâ€™s conduct giving rise to the mistrial was
  intended to â€œgoadâ€ or provoke the defendant into moving for the mistrial.Â  Oregon
    v. Kennedy, 456 U.S. 667, 676 (1982); State v. Mathis, 359 S.C. 450,
  460, 597 S.E.2d 872, 877 (Ct. App. 2004) (applying same standard in South Carolina).
Thus,
  the determination of whether double jeopardy attaches depends upon whether the
  prosecutorial misconduct was undertaken with the intent to subvert the rights
  protected by the Double Jeopardy Clause.Â  Coleman, 365 S.C. at 263, 616
  S.E.2d at 447.Â  â€œThe trial courtâ€™s finding concerning the prosecutorâ€™s intent
  is a factual one and will not be disturbed on appeal unless clearly
  erroneous.â€Â  Id.; see also Mathis, 359 S.C. at 460-61, 597
  S.E.2d at 877-78 (stating deference should be given to the trial courtâ€™s
  determination of the existence of the prosecutorâ€™s intent). 
We first must pay
  deference to Judge Hayesâ€™ letter indicating he did not rule on the jeopardy
  issue in granting the motion for a mistrial at the end of the first trial.Â  At
  the second trial, Judge Few first denied the motion to dismiss based on the
  jury deadlock.Â  We need not address this issue as we are restricted in our
  review of his further factual finding that the
  solicitor had not intentionally goaded the defense into moving for a mistrial.Â 
  We find support in the record to affirm the finding that the solicitor did not
  intentionally goad Parker into moving for a mistrial.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  court did not err in denying the motion to dismiss based on double jeopardy. 
CONCLUSION 
For the foregoing
  reasons, the conviction is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  KONDUROS, J., concur.

title: Mazloom v. Mazloom
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the Master-in-Equity's finding that Iraj Mazloom owned a 25% interest in the business at issue.  The Court also affirmed the master's decision to award Iraj both actual and punitive damages, but the Court modified the actual damages award to reflect the proper fair market value of the business.
